G. 1, 472</bibl></cit>.—So, adflari sidere = siderari, <hi rend="ital">to be seized with torpor</hi> or <hi rend="ital">paralysis</hi> (v. sideror and sideratio), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 41, 41, § 108</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">odores, qui adflarentur e floribus,</quote> <trans><tr>were wafted</tr>, <tr>exhaled</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:27:17" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 27, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1490.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to blow</hi> or <hi rend="ital">breathe to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">on.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1490.2" n="A" level="2"> As <hi rend="ital">v. act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bring to;</hi> constr. <hi rend="ital">alicui aliquid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sperat sibi auram posse aliquam adflari voluntatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rumoris nescio quid adflaverat, frequentiam non fuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 5</bibl></cit>: alicui aliquid mali faucibus adflare, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 49</bibl>.—So <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: adflare alicui honores, <hi rend="ital">to breathe beauty upon one</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to impart to</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:591" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 591</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">indomitis gregibus Venus adflat amores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:4:57" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 4, 57</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1490.3" n="B" level="2"> As <hi rend="ital">v. neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be favorable to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be friendly</hi> or <hi rend="ital">propitious to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Felix, cui placidus leniter adflat Amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:1:80" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 1, 80</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affluens: <entryFree id="n1491" type="main" key="affluens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">affluens</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, of affluo. <cb n="AFFR" /></entryFree>
affluenter: <entryFree id="n1492" type="main" key="afflu^enter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">afflŭenter</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <pos>adv.</pos>, v. affluo, <sense id="n1492.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
affluentia: <entryFree id="n1493" type="main" key="afflu^enti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">afflŭentĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>affluo</etym>, <sense id="n1493.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a flowing to</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 10, 61, § 94</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">affluence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abundance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">copiousness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fulness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">profusion</hi>: ex hac copiā atque rerum omnium adfluentiā, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">annonae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:29" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 29</bibl></cit>.—Hence also, <hi rend="ital">immoderate pomp</hi> or <hi rend="ital">splendor in the management of one's household</hi>, <hi rend="ital">extravagance</hi> (opp. mundities): <cit><quote lang="la">munditiem, non adfluentiam affectabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:13:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 13, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affluo: <entryFree id="n1494" type="main" key="afflu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-flŭo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>xi, xum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1494.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to flow</hi> or <hi rend="ital">run to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <case>dat.</case> </sense><sense id="n1494.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of water: <cit><quote lang="la">aestus bis adfluunt bisque remeant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:212" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 97, 99, § 212</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Rhenus ad Gallicam ripam placidior adfluens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 6</bibl></cit>.—In the lang. of the Epicurean philos., of the flow of atoms from an object, as the cause of perception (cf. aestus, II. C.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:19:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 19, 49</bibl>.— <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of time: Maecenas meus adfluentes Ordinat annos, <hi rend="ital">flowing on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increasing</hi>, = accrescentes, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:11:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 11, 19</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1494.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1494.3" n="A" level="2"> Of persons, <hi rend="ital">to come to in haste</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hasten to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to run</hi> or <hi rend="ital">flock to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in the histt. from the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">ingentem comitum adfluxisse Invenio numerum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:796" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 796</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">copiae adfluebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adfluentibus auxiliis Gallorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multitudo adfluens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 41</bibl></cit>.— Of food, <hi rend="ital">to flow down</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cibo adfluente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:44" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 44</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">si ea sola voluptas esset, quae ad eos (sensus) cum suavitate adflueret et inlaberetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil ex istis locis litterarum adfluxit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">incautis amor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. A. 148</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opes adfluunt subito, repente dilabuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:6:9" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 6, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1494.4" n="B" level="2"> Aliquā re, <hi rend="ital">to flow with a thing in rich abundance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to overflow with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to abound in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to have in abundance</hi> (more elevated than <hi rend="ital">abundo;</hi> hence adfluens in Cic. Oratt. is much more freq. than <hi rend="ital">abundans</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">frumento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitiis honore et laude,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluptatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:28:93" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 28, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui cum domi otium atque divitiae adfluerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 36:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 36, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi effuse adfluunt opes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 26</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">afflŭ-ens</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">flowing abundantly with a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">having in abundance</hi> or <hi rend="ital">superfluity; abounding in; abundant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rich</hi>, <hi rend="ital">copious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">numerous</hi>: Asiatico ornatu, Liv. Andron. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">unguentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbs eruditissimis hominibus, liberalissimisque studiis adfluens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 66</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:16 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 16 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">uberiores et adfluentiores aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 8, 1</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo vestitu adfluens,</quote> <trans><tr>in ample</tr>, <tr>flowing robes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:5:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 5, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex adfluenti,</quote> <trans><tr>in abundance</tr>, <tr>profusely</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:57 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 57 al.</bibl></cit>—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, Sol. c. 50; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Conf. 2:6" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Conf. 2, 6</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">afflŭente</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <hi rend="ital">richly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">copiously</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:6" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 54</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
affodio: <entryFree id="n1495" type="hapax" key="affo^di^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-fŏdĭo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ĕre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1495.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to dig in addition to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vicini caespitem nostro solo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:175" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 68, 68, § 175</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affor: <entryFree id="n1496" type="main" key="affor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-for</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> (used only in the <sense id="n1496.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pres. indic.</hi>, but not in first person sing.; in the <hi rend="ital">perf. part.</hi>, the <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, and in the <hi rend="ital">imper.</hi>, second person); in gen. only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to speak to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accost</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">address one</hi>: quem neque tueri contra neque affari queas, Att.ap.<bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> 6, 1</bibl>: licet enim versibus eisdem mihi adfari te, Attice, quibus adfatur Flamininum ille, *<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem nomine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:72:253" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 72, 253</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:492" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 492</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostem supplex adfare superbum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 424</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem blande,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 1, 251</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi me adfamini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 11</bibl></cit>: adfari deos, <hi rend="ital">to pray to the gods</hi>, Att. ap <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 111, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:700" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 700</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">precando Adfamur Vestam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:303" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 303</bibl></cit>: adfari mortuum, <hi rend="ital">to bid farewell to the dead at the burial</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take the last adieu</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic positum adfati discedite corpus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:644" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 644</bibl></cit>.—So also: <cit><quote lang="la">adfari extremum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:484" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 484</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1496.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp.. in augurial lang., <hi rend="ital">to fix the limits of the auspices</hi>: effari templa dicuntur ab auguribus; <cit><quote lang="la">adfantur qui in his fines sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=53" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 53</bibl></cit> Müll. (where the <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> use of the word should be observed; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 265, 39</bibl> Elm.).</sense></entryFree>
affore: <entryFree id="n1497" type="main" key="affo^re"><orth extent="full" lang="la">affŏre</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>) and <orth extent="full" lang="la">affŏrem</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), v. adsum.</entryFree>
afformido: <entryFree id="n1498" type="hapax" key="afformi_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-formīdo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1498.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be afraid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">magis cura'st magisque adformido, ne is pereat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 10, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affrango: <entryFree id="n1499" type="main" key="affrango"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-frango</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ĕre</itype> (or <orth extent="full" lang="la">adfringo</orth>,<pb n="69" /> <cb n="AFRI" />  ĕre), <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1499.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to strike upon</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">to break against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">break in pieces</hi> (very rare, perh. only in Statius): <cit><quote lang="la">duris adfrangunt postibus ungues,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:10:47" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 10, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plenis parvos uberibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hiemes bustis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:5:1:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> S. 5, 1, 36</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affremo: <entryFree id="n1500" type="main" key="affre^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-frĕmo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1500.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to roar</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">growl</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">murmur at</hi> (only in post-Aug. poets): <cit><quote lang="la">adfremit his (Mars),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:528" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 528</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Boreas stridentibus adfremit alis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:124" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 124</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affricatio: <entryFree id="n1501" type="main" key="affri^ca_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">affrĭcātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>affrico</etym>, <sense id="n1501.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rubbing on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against</hi> a thing, Cael. Aur. Morb. Acut. praef. n. 131; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:ib. 1:14:106" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 14, 106</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
affrico: <entryFree id="n1502" type="main" key="affri^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-frĭco</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>āre, ui, ātum</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1502.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to rub on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against</hi> a thing: alicui (only in post-Aug. prose). </sense><sense id="n1502.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">herbae se adfricans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 27, 41, § 99</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 29, 6, 38, § 122</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">unguedine diu palmulis suis adfricata,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 3, 138</bibl></cit> Elm.—</sense><sense id="n1502.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to communicate</hi> or <hi rend="ital">impart by rubbing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rubiginem suam alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affrictus: <entryFree id="n1503" type="hapax" key="affrictus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">affrictus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>affrico</etym>, <sense id="n1503.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rubbing on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Spuma aquae adfrictu verrucas tollit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 6, 38, § 72</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affringo: <entryFree id="n1504" type="main" key="affringo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">affringo</orth>, v. affrango.</entryFree>
affrio: <entryFree id="n1505" type="hapax" key="affri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-frĭo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1505.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to rub</hi> or <hi rend="ital">crumble to pieces</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">to crumble over</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alius aliud adfriat aut adspergit, ut Chalcidicam aut Caricam cretam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:57" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 57</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
affulgeo: <entryFree id="n1506" type="main" key="affulge^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-fulgĕo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ulsi, 2</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1506.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to shine on</hi> a thing (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>, and in the Aug. and post-Aug. histt.). </sense><sense id="n1506.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non Venus adfulsit, non illā Juppiter horā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:213" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 213</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nitenti Adfulsit vultu ridens Venus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:467" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 467</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">instar veris vultus tuus Adfulsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 5, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1506.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to shine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dawn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">appear</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">defensurum se urbem prima spes adfulsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 28</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi talis fortuna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lux civitati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cretensibus nihil praesidii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:7:6:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 7, 6, 1</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">ext.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">occasio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:9 al" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 9 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
affundo: <entryFree id="n1507" type="main" key="affundo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">af-fundo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">adf-</orth>), <itype>ūdi, ūsum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <sense id="n1507.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To pour to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">upon</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">into</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to sprinkle</hi> or <hi rend="ital">scatter on</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose). </sense><sense id="n1507.1" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">adfusa eis aqua calida,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 21, 46, § 102</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adfuso vino,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:144" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 9, 38, § 144</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 16, 44, 91, § 242</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Rhenum Oceano,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 5, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adfundere alicui venenum in aquā frigidā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 13, 16</bibl></cit>.—Hence: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis adfusus oppidis,</quote> <trans><tr>that flows by</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:29:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 31</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">oppidum adfusum amne,</quote> <trans><tr>washed by a river</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 3, 4, § 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1507.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to add to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to send</hi> or <hi rend="ital">despatch to</hi> some place <hi rend="ital">in haste</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equorum tria milia cornibus adfunderentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adfundere vitam alicui,</quote> <trans><tr>to give life</tr>, <tr>vitality</tr>, <tr>to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 6, 28</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1507.3" n="II" level="1"> Adfundere se or adfundi, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to cast one's self to</hi> the ground: adfusa (<hi rend="ital">stretched out</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prostrate</hi>) poscere vitam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:605" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 605</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adfusaeque jacent tumulo,</quote> <trans><tr>prostrate upon the tomb</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:539" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 539</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:686" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 686</bibl>.—In prose: <cit><quote lang="la">Cleopatra adfusa genibus Caesaris,</quote> <trans><tr>throwing herself at</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:2" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
afore: <entryFree id="n1508" type="main" key="a_fo^re"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āfŏre</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">āfŏrem</orth>, <itype>for abfore and abforem</itype>, v. absum.</entryFree>
afranius: <entryFree id="n1509" type="main" key="Afra_ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrānĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1509.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman</hi> gens.—</sense><sense id="n1509.1" n="I" level="1"> As <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">Afrania fabula,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>written by the poet Afranius</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 30</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1509.2" n="II" level="1"> As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1509.3" n="A" level="2"> Lucius Afranius, <hi rend="ital">a celebrated Roman comic poet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contemporary with Terence or a little later</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of whose works we possess only a few fragments.</hi> Cf. concerning him, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 57</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:100" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 100</bibl>; Bähr, Röm. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. S. 70, and Teuffel, Röm. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> §§ 121, 135.—</sense><sense id="n1509.4" n="B" level="2"> Afranius, <hi rend="ital">a general of Pompey in Spain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 16, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:48" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 48</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrānĭā-nus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Afranius</hi>: legio, Auct. B. Hisp. 7.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrā-nĭāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">soldiers of Afranius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 43</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
afri: <entryFree id="n1510" type="main" key="Afri"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Afri</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, v. Afer.</entryFree>
africa: <entryFree id="n1511" type="main" key="Afri^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrĭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>the Romans received this name from the Carthaginians as designating their country, and in this sense only the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">h( *)afrikh/</foreign> occurs</etym>. <sense id="n1511.0" n="I" level="1"> In a restricted sense, designated by the Greeks <foreign lang="greek">h( *libu/h</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Libya</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the territory of Carthage</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nilus Africam ab Aethiopiā dispescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 9, 10, § 53</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 4, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">regio, quae sequitur a promontorio Metagonio ad aras Philaenorum, proprie nomen Africae usurpat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 7</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 12</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:chapter=7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 7</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n1511.1" n="II" level="1"> In an extended sense, <hi rend="ital">the whole of that quarter of the globe south of the Mediterranean Sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 4</bibl>.—By meton. for <hi rend="ital">its inhabitants</hi>:<cb n="AGAS" />  Africa, quae procul a mari incultius agebat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 89:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 89, 7</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 19:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 19, 5</bibl>: alios incultius vagos agitare).—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1511.2" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrĭcānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Africa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">African</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum Africanum,</quote> <trans><tr>the war of Cœsar with the partisans of Pompey in Africa</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rumores,</quote> <trans><tr>of the African war</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">possessiones,</quote> <trans><tr>in Africa</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gallina,</quote> <trans><tr>a guinea-hen</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 9</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 26, 38, § 74</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrĭcānae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, sc. ferae, <hi rend="ital">panthers</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 18</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 17, 24, § 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 34</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Cat. 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 21 al.</bibl>—Esp., <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrĭcā-nus</orth>, <hi rend="ital">surname of the two most distinguished Scipios.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1511.3" n="A" level="2"> Of P. Cornelius Scipio major, who defeated Hannibal at Zama (201 B. C.). —</sense><sense id="n1511.4" n="B" level="2"> Of his grandson by adoption, P. Cornelius Scipio Aemilianus minor, who conducted the third Punic war, destroyed Carthage (146 B.C.), and subjected the whole Carthaginian territory to the Romans.— </sense><sense id="n1511.5" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">African</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for the prose Africanus): terra, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:42:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 42, 167</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bella,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:17:11" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 17, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vicus,</quote> <trans><tr>a place in Rome</tr>, <tr>on the Esquiline Hill</tr>, <tr>where the Carthaginian hostages were held in custody</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 5:32:44" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 5, 32, 44</bibl></cit>.—But esp. freq., <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrĭcus ventus</orth>, or <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Afrĭcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the south-west wind</hi>, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">li/y</foreign>, blowing between Auster and Favonius (<foreign lang="greek">libo/notos</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">ze/furos</foreign>), opp. Vulturnus (<foreign lang="greek">kaiki/as</foreign>), now called, among the Italians, <hi rend="ital">Affrico</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gherbino;</hi> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 47, 46, § 119</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 5:16" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 5, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">creberque procellis Africus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeceps,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 3, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luctans,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestilens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 23, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">protervus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 16, 22</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: procellae, <hi rend="ital">the waves</hi> or <hi rend="ital">storms caused by the</hi> Africus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:29:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 29, 57</bibl>.—In Propert., Africus, <hi rend="ital">as the god of this wind</hi>, is called pater, 5, 3, 48, but Müll. here reads <hi rend="ital">Aetheris.</hi></sense></entryFree>
afui: <entryFree id="n1512" type="main" key="a_fu^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āfŭi</orth>, <itype>afuturus</itype>, for abf-, v. absum.</entryFree>
agamedes: <entryFree id="n1513" type="main" key="A^ga^me_de_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgămēdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agamh/dhs</foreign>, <sense id="n1513.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a brother of Trophonius</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with whom he built the temple to the Delphic Apollo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:47:114" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 47, 114</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agamemnon: <entryFree id="n1514" type="main" key="A^ga^memnon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgămemnon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<case>nom.</case> Agamemno, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:8:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 8, 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Achill. 1, 553</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">*)agame/mnwn</foreign>, <sense id="n1514.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">king of Mycenœ</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Atreus and of Aërope</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother of Menelaüs</hi>, <hi rend="ital">husband of Clytœmnestra</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Orestes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Iphigenia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and Electra</hi>, <hi rend="ital">commander-in-chief of the Grecian forces before Troy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and murdered by his wife</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with the aid of Ægisthus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">her paramour.</hi>—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, for <hi rend="ital">his time</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vixēre fortes ante Agamemnona Multi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:9:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 9, 25</bibl></cit>- 28.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1514.1" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgămemnŏnĭdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agamemnoni/dhs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Agamemnon; his son Orestes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">par Agamemnonidae crimen,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the matricide of Orestes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:215" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 215</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1514.2" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgămem-nŏnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agamemno/nios</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Agamemnon</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">phalanges,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the Grecian troops before Troy</tr>, <tr>commanded by Agamemnon</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:489" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 489</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Mycenae,</quote> <trans><tr>ruled by Agamemnon</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 838</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Orestes,</quote> <trans><tr>son of Agamemnon</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 471</bibl></cit>: puella, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Agamemnon</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Iphigenia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:1:111" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 1, 111</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agamus: <entryFree id="n1515" type="main" key="a^ga^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgămus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/gamos</foreign>, <sense id="n1515.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">unmarried</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> adv. Jovian. 1</bibl> and 15.</sense></entryFree>
aganippe: <entryFree id="n1516" type="main" key="A^ga^nippe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgănippē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agani/pph</foreign>. <sense id="n1516.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A fountain in Bœotia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on Mount Helicon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sacred to the Muses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and giving poetical inspiration</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aonie Aganippe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:10:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 10, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Ep. ad Ser. 61</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1516.1" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgă-nippēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agani/ppeios</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the fountain of Aganippe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lyra, i. e. Musarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:3:20" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 3, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Laud. Ser. 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1516.2" n="2" level="3"> * <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgănippis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">that is sacred to the Muses</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fontes Aganippidos Hippocrenes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:7" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1516.3" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The wife of Acrisius and mother of Danaë</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 63" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 63</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agape: <entryFree id="n1517" type="greek" key="a^ga^pe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgăpē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ga/ph</foreign> (love). <sense id="n1517.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Christian love</hi> or <hi rend="ital">charity</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> ad Martyr. 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1517.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The love-feast of the early Christians</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 39 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
agaricum: <entryFree id="n1518" type="greek" key="a^ga^ri^cum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgărĭcum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agariko/n</foreign>, <sense id="n1518.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">larch fungus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tinder fungus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 9, 57, § 103</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:8:48" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 8, 48</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agaso: <entryFree id="n1519" type="main" key="a^ga_so"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgāso</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ago, as Sanscr. agas from ag; v. ago</etym>, <sense id="n1519.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a driver</hi>, but esp. <hi rend="ital">one who drives and takes care of horses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a hostler</hi>, <cb n="AGER" /> <hi rend="ital">groom</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 5, 2, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">duo equi cum agasonibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agasonem cum equo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:11:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 11, 40</bibl></cit>, n. 29.—</sense><sense id="n1519.1" n="II" level="1"> Contemptuously, <hi rend="ital">a low servant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lackey</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si patinam frangat agaso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:8:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 8, 72</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:76" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 76</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agathocles: <entryFree id="n1520" type="main" key="A^ga^tho_^cles"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgăthō^cles</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agaqoklh=s</foreign>. <sense id="n1520.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king of Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of a potter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">celebrated for his war with the Carthaginians for the possession of the island;</hi> cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:7:4:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 7, 4, 1</bibl> <hi rend="ital">ext.;</hi> and esp. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:22:1 sq" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 22, 1 sq.</bibl>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgăthō^clēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agaqo/kleios</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to King Agathocles</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tropaea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:652" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 652</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1520.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The author of a history of Cyzicus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 24</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agathodaemon: <entryFree id="n1521" type="greek" key="a^ga^tho^daemon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgăthŏdaemon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gaqodai/mwn</foreign> (good genius), <sense id="n1521.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of serpent in Egypt to which healing power was ascribed</hi>, Coluber Aesculapii, Linn.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Heliog. 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agathyrna: <entryFree id="n1522" type="main" key="A^ga^thyrna"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgăthyrna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aga/qurnon</foreign>, Strab., <sense id="n1522.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town on the northern coast of Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Tyndaris and Calacta</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:12" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:259" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 259</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:5" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agathyrsi: <entryFree id="n1523" type="main" key="A^ga^thyrsi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgăthyrsi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aga/qursoi</foreign>, <sense id="n1523.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Scythian people</hi> (<hi rend="ital">in what is now Transylvania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and the Bannat of Temeswar</hi>) <hi rend="ital">who commonly painted their faces and limbs;</hi> hence Vergil: picti Agathyrsi, A. 4, 146; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:12:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 26</bibl>; and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:1" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agave: <entryFree id="n1524" type="main" key="A^ga_ve_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgāvē</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgauē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agau/h</foreign>. <sense id="n1524.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A daughter of Cadmus and Harmonia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wife of Echion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Thebes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who tore in pieces with her own hands her son Pentheus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">because he cast contempt upon the orgies of Bacchus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:725" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 725</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 184" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 184</bibl> and 240.—</sense><sense id="n1524.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the Nereids</hi>, Hyg. praef. ad Fab.—</sense><sense id="n1524.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the Amazons</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 163" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 163</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
age: <entryFree id="n1525" type="main" key="a^ge"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăge</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgĕdum</orth>, v. ago, II. 12.</entryFree>
agea: <entryFree id="n1526" type="gloss" key="age_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agēa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1526.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a gangway in a ship</hi>, so called, acc. to Festus, quod in eā maxime quaeque res <hi rend="ital">agi</hi> solet, p. 9 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
agelastus: <entryFree id="n1527" type="greek" key="A^ge^lastus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgĕlastus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ge/lastos</foreign> (not laughing), <sense id="n1527.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surname of M. Crassus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandfather of the triumvir of the same name</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 19, 18, § 79</bibl>; cf. Lucil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:30:92" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 30, 92</bibl>, and Tusc. 3, 15, 31.</sense></entryFree>
agellulus: <entryFree id="n1528" type="main" key="a^gellu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgellŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>a double <lbl>dim.</lbl> of ager; cf. asellulus</etym>, <sense id="n1528.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very small field</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 2:30" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 2, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agellus: <entryFree id="n1529" type="main" key="a^gellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgellus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>ager</etym>, <sense id="n1529.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small piece of ground</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a little field;</hi> Agelli est hic sub urbe paulum quod locitas foras, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:8:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 8, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agellus non sane major jugero uno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minora dii neglegunt, neque agellos singulorum nec viticulas persequuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 35</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agema: <entryFree id="n1530" type="greek" key="a^ge_ma^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgēmă</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/ghma</foreign>, in the Macedonian army, <sense id="n1530.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a corps</hi> or <hi rend="ital">division of soldiers</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">addita his ala mille ferme equitum: agema eam vocabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:51" default="NO" valid="yes">42, 51</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 42, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:13:26" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 13, 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agendicum: <entryFree id="n1531" type="main" key="A^gendi^cum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgendĭcum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1531.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Gallia Lugdunensis</hi>, acc. to the Tabul. Peuting. Agedicum, now <hi rend="ital">Sens</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 44</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agenor: <entryFree id="n1532" type="main" key="A^ge_nor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgēnor</orth>, <itype>ŏris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)agh/nwr</foreign>, <sense id="n1532.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of Belus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Phœnicia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Cadmus and Europa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and ancestor of Dido;</hi> hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, Agenoris urbs, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Carthage</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:338" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 338</bibl>.—Agenore natus, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Cadmus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 51</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">97</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">257</bibl>.—Whence, derivv. </sense><sense id="n1532.1" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgēnŏrĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Agenor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">bos,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Jupiter</tr>, <tr>who</tr>, <tr>in the form of a bull</tr>, <tr>carried off Europa</tr>, <tr>the daughter of Agenor</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:712" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 712</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aëna,</quote> <trans><tr>Phœnician</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:642" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 642</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:16" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 16</bibl>.—Also for <hi rend="ital">Carthaginian</hi> (cf. Agenor), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:14" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nepotes,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>the Carthaginians</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:17:404" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 17, 404</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ductor,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>Hannibal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:17:392" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 17, 392</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1532.2" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgēnŏrĭdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Agenor.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1532.3" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">His son Cadmus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 8</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:3:81" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 81</bibl>; 90; 4, 562; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:3:77" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 1, 3, 77</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1532.4" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Perseus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whose grandfather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the mother's side</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Danaüs</hi>, <hi rend="ital">was descended from Agenor</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:771" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 771</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agens: <entryFree id="n1533" type="main" key="a^gens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, v. <itype>ago</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
ager: <entryFree id="n1534" type="main" key="a^ger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăger</orth>, <itype>gri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)gro/s</foreign>; Germ. Acker, Eng. acre, Sanscr. agras = surface, floor; Grimm conjectured that it was connected with ago, <foreign lang="greek">a)/gw</foreign>, a pecore agendo, and this was the ancient view; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=34" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 34</bibl> Müll., and Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 47</bibl>; so the Germ. Trift = pasture, from treiben, to drive</etym>. <sense id="n1534.0" n="I" level="1"> In an extended sense, <hi rend="ital">territory</hi>, <hi rend="ital">district</hi>, <hi rend="ital">domain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the whole of the soil belonging to a community</hi> (syn.: terra, tellus, arvum, solum, rus, humus; opp. terra, which includes <pb n="70" /> <cb n="AGGE" /> many such possessions taken together; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Nieb. Röm. Gesch. 2, 694 sq.): Ager Tusculanus, ... non terra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:2:84" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, 2, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedā atque agro adfecit familiares suos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abituros agro Achivos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 53, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut melior fundus Hirpinus sit, sive ager Hirpinus (totum enim possidet), quam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 3, 2</bibl></cit>: fundum habet in agro Thurino, id. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:2:131" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 2, 131</bibl> (pro Tull. 14): <cit><quote lang="la">Rhenus, qui agrum Helvetium a Germanis dividit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 2</bibl></cit> Herz.: <cit><quote lang="la">ager Noricus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in agro Troade,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,004:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Paus. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in agro Aretino,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 36:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 36, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">his civitas data agerque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in agro urbis Jericho,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Josue, 5, 13</bibl></cit>.—In the Roman polity: ager Romanus, <hi rend="ital">the Roman possessions in land</hi> (distinguished from <hi rend="ital">ager peregrinus</hi>, foreign territory) was divided into ager publicus, <hi rend="ital">public property</hi>, <hi rend="ital">domains</hi>, and ager privatus, <hi rend="ital">private estates;</hi> v. Smith's Dict. Antiq., and Nieb. Röm. Gesch. 2, 695 and 696; cf. with 153 sq.—</sense><sense id="n1534.1" n="II" level="1"> In a more restricted sense. </sense><sense id="n1534.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Improdued</hi> or <hi rend="ital">productive land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a field</hi>, whether pasture, arable, nursery ground, or any thing of the kind; cf. Doed. Syn. 3, 7 sq.; 1, 71; Hab. Syn. 68, and Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agrum hunc mercatus sum: hic me exerceo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agrum de nostro patre colendum habebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ager quamvis fertilis, sine culturā fructuosus esse non potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agrum colere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conserere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agrum tuum non seres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:19:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 19, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(homo) seminavit bonum semen in agro suo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:13:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 13, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:12:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 12, 16</bibl>. —* Of a piece of ground where vines or trees are planted, <hi rend="ital">a nursery</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ager mundus purusque flat, ejus arbor atque vitis fecundior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:12:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 12, 8</bibl></cit>.—Of a place of habitation in the country, <hi rend="ital">estate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">villa</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in tuosne agros confugiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 15</bibl></cit> (so <foreign lang="greek">a)gro/s</foreign>, Hom. Od. 24, 205).—</sense><sense id="n1534.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The fields</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the open country</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the country</hi> (as in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)gro/s</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">a)groi/</foreign>), like rus, in opp. to the town, urbs (in prose writers generally only in the <number>plur.</number>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 5, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines ex agris concurrunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non solum ex urbe, sed etiam ex agris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 4, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">annus pestilens urbi agrisque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in civitatem et in agros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 5, 14</bibl></cit>.—And even in opp. to a village or hamlet, <hi rend="ital">the open field</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanum hominem modo ruri esse oportet, modo in urbe, saepiusque in agro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1534.4" n="C" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, in opp. to mountains, <hi rend="ital">plain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">valley</hi>, <hi rend="ital">champaign</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignotos montes agrosque salutat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1534.5" n="D" level="2"> As <hi rend="ital">a measure of length</hi> (opp. frons, <hi rend="ital">breadth</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">mille pedes in fronte, trecentos cippus in agrum Hic dabat,</quote> <trans><tr>in depth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 8, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ageraton: <entryFree id="n1535" type="greek" key="a^ge_ra^ton"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgērăton</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gh/raton</foreign> (not growing old), <sense id="n1535.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant that does not readily wither</hi>, perhaps Achillea Ageraton, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 4, 4, § 13</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgērătos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a designation of one of the Æons of Valentinus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agesilaus: <entryFree id="n1536" type="main" key="A^ge_si^la_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgēsĭlāüs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aghsi/laos</foreign>. <sense id="n1536.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One of the most valiant of the Spartan kings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who conquered the Persian satrap Tissaphernes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and the Athenians and Boeotians at Coronea.</hi> Plutarch and also Nepos wrote his life.—* </sense><sense id="n1536.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An epithet of Pluto</hi> (from his driving (<foreign lang="greek">a)/gw</foreign>) all people into his kingdom), <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 1, 11, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agesis: <entryFree id="n1537" type="main" key="a^ge^si_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgĕsīs</orth>, i. e. age sis, v. ago, II. 12.</entryFree>
aggaudeo: <entryFree id="n1538" type="main" key="aggaude^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ag-gaudĕo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>ēre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1538.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be delighted with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to delight in</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">ego eram, cui aggaudebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 4, 6</bibl></cit>; transl. of <foreign lang="greek">e)gw\ h)/mhn h(=| prose/xairen</foreign>, LXX. Prov. 8, 30.</sense></entryFree>
aggemo: <entryFree id="n1539" type="main" key="agge^mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ag-gĕmo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>ĕre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1539.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to groan</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wail</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lament</hi> at a thing; <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> or with <case>dat.</case> (only <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">Adgemit Alcides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:400" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 400</bibl></cit>, where Riese has <hi rend="ital">Et gemit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Adgemit et nostris ipsa carina malis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:4:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 1, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">uterque loquenti adgemit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:247" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 11, 247</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aggenero: <entryFree id="n1540" type="main" key="agge^ne^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ag-gĕnĕro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1540.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to beget in addition to</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 4, 19</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aggeniculor: <entryFree id="n1541" type="main" key="agge^ni^cu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aggĕnĭcŭlor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>genu, geniculum</etym>, <sense id="n1541.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bow the knee before</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to kneel before</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Poen. 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agger: <entryFree id="n1542" type="main" key="agger"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agger</orth>, <itype>ĕris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ad-gero</etym>. <sense id="n1542.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Things brought to</hi> a place <hi rend="ital">in order to form an elevation above a surface</hi> or <hi rend="ital">plain</hi>, as <hi rend="ital">rubbish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stone</hi>, <hi rend="ital">earth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brushwood</hi>, <hi rend="ital">materials for a rampart</hi>, etc. (in the histt., esp. Cæs., freq.; sometimes in the poets): ab opere revocandi milites, qui paulo longius aggeris<cb n="AGGE" />  petendi causā processerant, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aggere paludem explere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 58</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 86</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">longius erat agger petendus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 1, 42</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 15 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">superjecto aggere terreno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:19" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 19</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">implere cavernas aggere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:10:27" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 10, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fossas aggere complent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:567" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 567</bibl></cit>: avis e medio aggere exit, <hi rend="ital">from the midst of the pile</hi> of wood, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:524" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 524</bibl>.— But far oftener, </sense><sense id="n1542.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1542.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The pile formed by masses of rubbish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stone</hi>, <hi rend="ital">earth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brushwood</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">collected together;</hi> acc. to its destination, <hi rend="ital">a dam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dike</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mole</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pier; a hillock</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mound</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wall</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bulwark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rampart</hi>, etc.; esp. freq. in the histt. of artificial elevations for military purposes: tertium militare sepimentum est fossa et terreus agger, <hi rend="ital">a clay</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mud wall</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:14:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 14, 2</bibl>: aggeribus niveis (<hi rend="ital">with snow-drifts</hi>) informis Terra, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:354" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 354</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque ipsis proelia miscent Aggeribus murorum, pleon. for muris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 10, 24</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 144</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut cocto tolleret aggere opus, of the walls of Babylon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:10:22" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 10, 22</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">A dike of earth</hi> for the protection of a harbor (Ital. molo), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:5:12:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 5, 12, 122</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:445" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 445</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">15, 690</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">A causeway</hi> through a swamp: <cit><quote lang="la">aggeres umido paludum et fallacibus campis imponere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 61</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">A heap</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pile</hi> of arms: <cit><quote lang="la">agger armorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 70</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, for <hi rend="ital">mountains</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aggeres Alpini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:830" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 830</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">Thessalici aggeres,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Pelion</tr>, <tr>Ossa</tr>, <tr>Olympus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 168" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 168</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">A funeral pile</hi> of wood, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:234" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 234</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Fur. 1216" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Fur. 1216</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">A heap</hi> of ashes: <cit><quote lang="la">ab alto aggere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:524" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 524</bibl></cit> Weber.— <hi rend="ital">A high wave</hi> of the sea: <cit><quote lang="la">ab alto Aggere dejecit pelagi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:674" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 674</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consurgit ingens pontus in vastum aggerem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 1015" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 1015</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">mons aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 105</bibl></cit>).— </sense><sense id="n1542.3" n="B" level="2"> In milit. lang. </sense><sense id="n1542.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A mound erected before the walls of a besieged city</hi>, <hi rend="ital">for the purpose of sustaining the battering engines</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and which was gradually advanced to the town;</hi> cf. Smith's Dict. Antiq., and Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aggere, vineis, turribus oppidum oppugnare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 15, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">esset agger oppugnandae Italiae Graecia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 10, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">celeriter vineis ad oppidum actis, aggere jacto turribusque constitutis, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jacere,</quote> <trans><tr>to throw up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 37:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 37, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:29:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 29, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aggerem exstruere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">instruere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">promovere ad urbem,</quote> <trans><tr>to bring near to the city</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 7</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: stellatis axibus agger Erigitur, geminasque aequantis moenia turres Accipit, <hi rend="ital">a mound is built provided with wheels</hi> (for moving it forwards), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:455" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 455</bibl>; imitated by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:109" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 109</bibl>.—Since such aggeres consisted principally of wood, they could be easily set on fire, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 14</bibl>: horae momento simul aggerem ac vineas incendium hausit, Liv 5, 7.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">Graecia esset vel receptaculum pulso Antonio, vel agger oppugnandae Italiae,</quote> <trans><tr>rampart</tr>, <tr>mound</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:10:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 10, 4</bibl></cit>: Agger Tarquini, <hi rend="ital">the mound raised by Tarquinius Superbus for the defence of the eastern part of the city of Rome</hi>, in the neighborhood of the present <hi rend="ital">Porta S. Lorenzo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 67</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:15:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 15, 24</bibl>, n. 2, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 8, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:5:153" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 5, 153</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:74" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 74</bibl>.—Suet. uses agger for <hi rend="ital">the Tarpeian rock</hi>: quoad praecipitaretur ex aggere, Calig. 27.—</sense><sense id="n1542.5" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The mound raised for the protection of a camp before the trench</hi> (fossa), <hi rend="ital">and from earth dug from it</hi>, which was secured by a stockade (vallum), consisting of sharpened stakes (valli); cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Hab. Syn. 68, and Smith's Dict. Antiq.: in litore sedes, Castrorum in morem pinnis atque aggere cingit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 159</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 14, 14, § 47</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1542.6" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The tribunal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in a camp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">formed of turf</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from which the general addressed his soldiers</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">stetit aggere saltus Cespitis, intrepidus vultum meruitque timeri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:317" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 317</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vix eā turre senex, cum ductor ab aggere coepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:374" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 374</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 18</bibl> Lips.—</sense><sense id="n1542.7" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A military</hi> or <hi rend="ital">public road</hi>, commonly graded by embankments of earth (in the class. per. only in Verg. and Tac., and always in connection with viae, agger alone belonging only to later Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">viae deprensus in aggere serpens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:273" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 273</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aurelius agger, i. e. via Aurelia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Rutil.</author> Itiner. 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aggerem viae tres praetoriae cohortes obtinuere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 24</bibl></cit> and 42; 3, 21 and 23.</sense></entryFree>
aggeratim: <entryFree id="n1543" type="hapax" key="agge^ra_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aggĕrātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>agger</etym>, <sense id="n1543.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in heaps</hi>, = acervatim, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 146, 2</bibl> Elm. <cb n="AGGR" /></sense></entryFree>
aggeratio: <entryFree id="n1544" type="main" key="agge^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aggĕrātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>1. aggero</etym>, <sense id="n1544.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a heaping up;</hi> in concr., <hi rend="ital">that which is heaped up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a mole</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dike</hi> (not before the Aug. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">naves supra adgerationem, quae fuerat sub aquā, sederunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:22:263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 22, 263</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 2, 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
aggero: <entryFree id="n1545" type="main" key="agge^ro1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aggĕro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>agger</etym>. <sense id="n1545.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to form an</hi> agger, or <hi rend="ital">to heap up like an</hi> agger; hence, in gen., <hi rend="ital">to heap up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pile up</hi> (cf. cumulare; only <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">aggerat cadavera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:556" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 556</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Laurentis praemia pugnae aggerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 11, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ossa disjecta vel aggerata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 61</bibl></cit>;
