<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 154</bibl></cit>.—And, as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> concr., of birds turba Agminis aligeri, <hi rend="ital">of the winged band</hi>, Verg A. 12, 249.—Of ants; <cit><quote lang="la">frugilegas aspeximus agmine longo formi cas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> M 7, 624</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:7:638" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 638</bibl>.—Of the stars: diffugiunt stellae; <cit><quote lang="la">quarum agmina cogit Lucifer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 114</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:11:97" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 97</bibl> al.—Eap. of a company of persons, <hi rend="ital">a multitude</hi>, <hi rend="ital">troop</hi>, <hi rend="ital">crowd</hi>, <hi rend="ital">number</hi>, <hi rend="ital">band</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut a Brundisic nsque Romam agmen perpetuum totius Italiae viderem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magno senatorum agmine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingens mulierum agmen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">muliebre et miserabile agmen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 40</bibl></cit>: numerosum agmen reorum, Plin Ep. 3, 9, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 6</bibl>: Eumenidum agmina, Verg A. 4, 469.—But particularly, </sense><sense id="n1581.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The train</hi>, <hi rend="ital">procession</hi>, <hi rend="ital">march</hi>, <hi rend="ital">progress</hi> of an army: <cit><quote lang="la">de castris, de agminibus, etc., dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:48:210" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 48, 210</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne miles gregarius in castris, neve in agmine servum aut jumentum haberet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 45:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 45, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pugnatum saepe directā acie, saepe in agminibus, saepe eruptionibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:47" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">effuso agmine abire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">uno agmine victores cum victis in urbem irrupere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 30</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">uno agmine persequentes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judith, 15, 4 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1581.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, concr., <hi rend="ital">an army</hi>, and properly <hi rend="ital">considered as in motion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the march</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">exercitus</hi> is a disciplined army, and <hi rend="ital">acies</hi> an army in battle-array) —As soon as the signal for marching was given, the Extraordinarii and the allies of the right wing, with their baggage, first put themselves in motion, then the legions, and last the allies of the left wing, with a part of the cavalry, which either rode behind the army, ad agmen claudendum or cogendum. to close the train, i. e. to keep it to gether or on the side in such an order (composito agmine, non itineri magis apto quam proelio) that it might be easily put into the line of battle, if the enemy ven tured to attack it; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 46:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 46, 6</bibl>.—An army in close ranks was called agmen justum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 68</bibl>, or agmen pilatum, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 12, 121</bibl>—When there was no apprehension of the enemy, less care was taken for the protection of the army: <cit><quote lang="la">agmine incauto, i. e. minus munito, ut inter pacatos, ducebat, sc. consul,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 4</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">The order of march was, however, different, according to circumstances and the nature of the ground,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:28" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 28</bibl>; and cf. Smith's Antiq.—Sometimes the army marched in the form of a square, agmen quadratum, with their baggage in the middle, so as to be in battle-array on meeting the enemy; hence agmen quadratum often means the same as acies triplex, <hi rend="ital">an army formed in line of battle</hi>, only that the former indicates that they are on the march, and the latter that they are at rest.—Hence, like acies, with the epithet <hi rend="ital">primum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the vanguard</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">medium,</quote> <trans><tr>the centre</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 41</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">extremum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 100</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">or, novissimum,</quote> <trans><tr>the rear</tr>, <tr>rearguard</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 33</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">extremi agminis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:25:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 25, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut inde agmine quadratc ad urbem accederet,</quote> <trans><tr>marching in a square</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pariter atque in conspectu hostium quadrato agmine incedere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J 100:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J 100, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 46:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 46, 6, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hannibal agmine quadrato amnem ingressus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 5</bibl></cit>; se <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 31, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:39" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quadrato agmine velut in aciem irent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:1:19 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 1, 19 al.</bibl></cit>—Sometimes, esp. in the poets in the <number>plur.</number>, in gen. <pb n="73" /> <cb n="AGNA" /> sense, = exercitus or copiae, <hi rend="ital">an army</hi>, <hi rend="ital">host</hi>, <hi rend="ital">troops</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">huic tanto agmini dux defuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 12, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">occidit Daci Cotisonis agmen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:8:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 8, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmina curru Proterit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:329" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 329</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbarorum Claudius agmina diruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:14:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 14, 29</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 1, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 17, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:535" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 535</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 151, 161</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 423</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Del agminum Israël,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:17:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 17, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmina ejus dispergam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:12:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Ezech. 12, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">38, 6</bibl>.—For <hi rend="ital">military service</hi>, <hi rend="ital">warfare</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rudis agminum Sponsus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1581.4" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1581.5" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">An army</hi>, <hi rend="ital">troop</hi>, <hi rend="ital">band</hi>, <hi rend="ital">multitude</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">educenda dictio est ex hac domesticā exercitatione et umbratili medium in agmen, in pulverem, in clamorem, in castra, aciemque forensem,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>before the public</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:34:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 34, 157</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">e Brundisio usque Romam agmen perpetuum totius Italiae,</quote> <trans><tr>an unbroken train</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:22:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 22, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingens mulierum agmen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:17" default="NO" valid="yes">9, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmina Eumenidum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:469" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 469</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 572</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmina comitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:14:30" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 14, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in angusto fidus comes agmine turbae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:5:63" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 5, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numerosum agmen reorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmen occupationum,</quote> <trans><tr>an army of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1581.6" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">March</hi>, <hi rend="ital">movement</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmina fati et volumina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:2:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 2, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agminalis: <entryFree id="n1582" type="main" key="agmi^na_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agmĭnālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>agmen</etym>, <sense id="n1582.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to a march</hi> or <hi rend="ital">train</hi> (only in the Pandects): <cit><quote lang="la">equi,</quote> <trans><tr>pack-horses</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:4:18:section=21" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 50, 4, 18, § 21</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: agminales, Cod. Th. 8, 5, 6.</sense></entryFree>
agminatim: <entryFree id="n1583" type="main" key="agmi^na_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agmĭnātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1583.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">by troops</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in trains</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in crowds</hi>, = gregatim (only in late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">elephanti oberrant agminatim,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 151, 35</bibl> Elm.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. p. 146, 2</bibl> Elm.</sense></entryFree>
agna: <entryFree id="n1584" type="main" key="agna1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (<sense id="n1584.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abl. plur.</hi> agnabus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Retr. 2, 55, 1</bibl>), <gen>f.</gen> <etym>agnus</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a ewe lamb</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:2:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:21:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 21, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">humilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:17:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 17, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pulla,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:8:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 8, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">muta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nitida,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 214</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">novella,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:118" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 118</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pavens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:527" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 6, 527</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:8:576" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 8, 576</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1585" type="gloss" key="agna2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1585.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a blade</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a straw</hi>, Fest. s. v. pennatus, p. 211 Müull. [kindr. with 2. acus, q. v.; cf. Aufrecht in Zeitschr. für vergl. Sprachf. 1, p. 354].</sense></entryFree>
agnalia: <entryFree id="n1586" type="gloss" key="Agna_li^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agnālĭa</orth> (com. <orth extent="full" lang="la">Agōnālĭa</orth>, q. v.), <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1586.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman festival</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pars putat hic festum priscis Agnalia dictum, Una sit ut proprio littera dempta loco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:325" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 325</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agnascor: <entryFree id="n1587" type="main" key="agnascor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">a-gnascor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>nātus, 3</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>ad-gnascor, nascor</etym>. <sense id="n1587.0" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To be born in addition to;</hi> commonly, </sense><sense id="n1587.1" n="A" level="2"> Of children that are not born until after the father has made his will: <cit><quote lang="la">constat agnascendo rumpi testamentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:57:241" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 57, 241</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:25:3:3" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 25, 3, 3</bibl>.—Metaph., </sense><sense id="n1587.2" n="B" level="2"> Of adopted children, <hi rend="ital">to accrue by adoption</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui in adoptionem datur, his, quibus agnascitur, cognatus fit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Dig. 1, 7, 23</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 7, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1587.3" n="II" level="1"> Of plants, <hi rend="ital">to grow to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">upon</hi> something: <cit><quote lang="la">viscum in quercu adgnasci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:245" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 44, 93, § 245</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:97" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 11, 73, § 97</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1587.4" n="III" level="1"> Of teeth, <hi rend="ital">to grow afterwards</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 10</bibl>.—Of hair, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 39, 94, § 231</bibl>. —Of limbs: <cit><quote lang="la">membra animalibus adgnata inutilia sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:272" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 52, 113, § 272</bibl></cit>.—Of plants: <cit><quote lang="la">tubera et cetera quae subito adgnascuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 82" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 82</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">agnā-tus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n1587.5" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">born to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">connected with by birth;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a blood relation</hi> by the father's side (<hi rend="ital">father</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandson</hi>, etc.; <hi rend="ital">brother</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother's son</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother's grandson</hi>, etc.; <hi rend="ital">uncle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cousin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">second cousin</hi>, etc.); accordingly of more limited signif. than <hi rend="ital">cognatus</hi>, which includes blood relations on the mother's side; the idea in <hi rend="ital">gentilis</hi> is still more extended, including all the persons belonging to a <hi rend="ital">gens</hi>, and bearing the same gentile name, e. g. the Cornelii, Fabii, Aemilii, etc., v. Smith's Dict. Antiq.; Gai <bibl default="NO"><author>Inst.</author> 1, 156</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ulp.</author> 26, 1, 10, § 2</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Zimmern, Röm. Priv. Rechtsgesch. 1, 507 sq.—Even the XII. Tables mention the Agnati: SI. (PATERFAMILIAS) INTESTATO. MORITVR. CVI. SVVS. HERES. NEC. SIT. ADGNATVS. PROXIMVS. FAMILIAM. HABETO.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 50</bibl></cit>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Ulp.</author> Fragm. Tit. 26, § 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">SI. ADGNATVS. NEC. ESCIT. (sit) GENTILIS. FAMILIAM. NANCITOR., Mos. et Rom. Leg. Coll. Tit. 16, § 4: SI. FVRIOSVS. EST. ADGNATORVM. GENTILIVMQVE. IN. EO. PECVNIAQVE. EIVS. POTESTAS. ESTO.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 1, 13</bibl>.—Hence, the proverb: <cit><quote lang="la">ad adgnatos et gentiles est deducendus, for a madman or insane person,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:2:8" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 2, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1587.6" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ag-nāti</orth>, <itype>orum</itype>, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">children born after</hi> the <cb n="AGNO" /> father has made his will (cf. I. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">numerum liberorum finire aut quemquam ex adgnatis necare flagitium habetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 5, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnaticius: <entryFree id="n1588" type="hapax" key="agna_ti_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnātīcĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>) or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>agnatus</etym>, <sense id="n1588.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the</hi> agnati: jus, <hi rend="ital">the right of the</hi> agnati <hi rend="ital">to enter upon an inheritance</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 6, 58, 15, § 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnatio: <entryFree id="n1589" type="main" key="agna_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n1589.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The relationship of the</hi> agnatus, <hi rend="ital">consanguinity on the father's side</hi> (v. agnatus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:7:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 7, 23</bibl> Creuz; <cit><quote lang="la">1, 8, 24: jura agnationum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:38:173" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 38, 173</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1589.1" n="II" level="1"> As a verbal <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> from agnascor, I. A. </sense><sense id="n1589.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A being born after the last will</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the death of the father</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:5:24:section=11" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 5, 24, § 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 3, 8, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1589.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A growing on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to</hi> a thing (acc. to agnascor, II.), <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 59</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnellus: <entryFree id="n1590" type="hapax" key="agnellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnellus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>agnus</etym>, <sense id="n1590.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little lamb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lambkin</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 77</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnicellus: <entryFree id="n1591" type="main" key="agnicellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnicellus</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">agnicellulus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1591.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a lambkin</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1321,001:Gr. p. 105" default="NO"><author>Pomp.</author> Gr. p. 105</bibl> Lindem.</sense></entryFree>
agniculus: <entryFree id="n1592" type="hapax" key="agni^cu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnĭcŭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1592.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a lambkin</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 7, p. 219</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agninus: <entryFree id="n1593" type="main" key="agni_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1593.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to a lamb</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)mnei/os</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n1593.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lactes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 3, 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">coagulum,</quote> <trans><tr>rennet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:11:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 11, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 8, 21, § 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus,</quote> <trans><tr>lamb-broth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 189" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 189</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1593.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">agnīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. caro), <hi rend="ital">the flesh of a lamb as eaten</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lamb</hi> (like porcina, <hi rend="ital">pork</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ferina,</quote> <trans><tr>venison</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 215</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitulina,</quote> <trans><tr>veal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 8, 4</bibl></cit>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 8, 4</bibl>: et duplā (<hi rend="ital">at double price</hi>) agninam danunt, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 39</bibl> Lind.: patinas cenabat omasi Vilis et agninae, * <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 15, 35</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnitio: <entryFree id="n1594" type="main" key="agni^ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnĭtĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>agnosco</etym>. <sense id="n1594.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A recognition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acknowledgment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">admission</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acceptance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admissio: bonorum possessionis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:15:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 15, 5</bibl></cit> (cf. agnosco, II.); <hi rend="ital">a recognizing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cadaveris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:194" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 70, 90, § 194</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullus interesset alienus agnitioni mutuae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:45:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 45, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1594.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A knowing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perceiving</hi>, <hi rend="ital">apprehending</hi>, <hi rend="ital">knowledge</hi>, in gen.: ad agnitionem animi, <hi rend="ital">for the knowledge of the nature of mind</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 1</bibl> Creuz: <cit><quote lang="la">ut impleamini agnitione,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Col. 1, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Somn. Scip. 1, 8</bibl>; Cassian. Incarn. 4, 2; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 8, 155</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnitionalis: <entryFree id="n1595" type="main" key="agni^ti^o_na_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnĭtĭōnālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>agnitio</etym>, <sense id="n1595.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that may be recognized</hi>, <hi rend="ital">known</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cognizable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">forma (Christi),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 27</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agnitor: <entryFree id="n1596" type="main" key="agni^tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnĭtor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>agnosco</etym>, <sense id="n1596.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that recognizes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">understands</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perceives</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">mediocritatis, Auct. Itin. Alex. Magn. 3: cordis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Vulg. Eccli. 7, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agnitus: <entryFree id="n1597" type="main" key="agni^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnĭtus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adg-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of agnosco.</entryFree>
agnomen: <entryFree id="n1598" type="main" key="agno_men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">a-gnōmen</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>gnomen, nomen</etym>, <sense id="n1598.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surname</hi> (this word seems to have been first employed in later Lat. by the gramm. in order to distinguish the surname of individuals, e. g. Africanus, Asiaticus, Cunctator, and the like, from that belonging to all the members of a family (the agnati), e. g. Scipio, Cicero, Cato, and the like; while both these ideas were, through the whole class. per., designated by <hi rend="ital">cognomen</hi>, q.v.: “propriorum nominum quattuor sunt species: Praenomen, Nomen, Cognomen, Agnomen: praenomen est quod nominibus gentilitiis praeponitur, ut Marcus, Publius; nomen proprium est gentilitium, id est, quod originem gentis vel familiae declarat, ut Portius, Cornelius; cognomen est quod uniuscujusque proprium est et nominibus gentilitiis subjungitur, ut Cato, Scipio; agnomen vero est quod extrinsecus cognominibus adici solet, ex aliquā ratione vel virtute quaesitum, ut est Africanus, Numantinus, et similia,” <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 306</bibl> P.; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 578</bibl> P. al.; Capit. Ver. 3.</sense></entryFree>
agnomentum: <entryFree id="n1599" type="hapax" key="agno_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnōmentum</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = agnomen: <sense id="n1599.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">lgitur agnomenta ei duo indita,</quote> <trans><tr>Charon—Mezentius</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. p. 310</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agnominatio: <entryFree id="n1600" type="main" key="agno_mi^na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnōmĭnātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1600.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the bringing together two words different in meaning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but similar in sound</hi>, <hi rend="ital">paronomasia</hi>, a rhet. fig., = <foreign lang="greek">paronomasi/a</foreign>: veniit a te antequam Romam venit. Hunc ăvium dulcedo ducit ad āvium. Si lenones tamquam leones vitāsset. Videte judices, utrum homini navo an vano credere malitis, etc., Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 21</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:66" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 66</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnos: <entryFree id="n1601" type="greek" key="agno^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/gnos</foreign> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">a(gno/s</foreign>, chaste), <cb n="AGNU" /> <sense id="n1601.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tall plant resembling the willow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the chastetree</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">agnus castus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 9, 38, § 59</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agnoscibilis: <entryFree id="n1602" type="hapax" key="agnosci^bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnoscĭbĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>agnosco</etym>, <sense id="n1602.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that can be known</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cognizable</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agnosco: <entryFree id="n1603" type="main" key="agnosco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnosco</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">adgn-</orth>; also <orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>; cf. Wagn. Orthog. <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> p. 407</bibl>), nōvi, nitum (like cognĭtum from cognosco; cf. pejĕro and dejĕro from jūro), <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, intens. -gnosco, nosco</etym> (<sense id="n1603.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi> agnōtus, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 887</bibl> P.; <hi rend="ital">part. fut. act.</hi> agnoturus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. Fragm. 2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. Fragm. 2, 31</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 383</bibl> P.; class.; used very freq. by Cicero). </sense><sense id="n1603.1" n="I" level="1"> As if <hi rend="ital">to know a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing well</hi>, as having known it before, to recognize: <hi rend="ital">agnoscere</hi> always denotes a subjective knowledge or recognition; while <hi rend="ital">cognoscere</hi> designates an objective perception; another distinction v. in II.): in turbā Oresti cognitā agnota est soror, <hi rend="ital">was recognized by Orestes as his sister</hi>, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 887</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">virtus cum se extollit et ostendit suum lumen et idem aspexit agnovitque in alio,</quote> <trans><tr>and when she has perceived the same in another</tr>, <tr>and has recognized it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:27:100" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 27, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id facillime accipiunt animi, quod agnoscunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:71" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum se collegit (animus) atque recreavit, tum agnoscit illa reminiscendo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:24:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 24, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod mihi de filiā gratularis, agnosco humanitatem tuam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 7</bibl></cit> (cf. on the contr. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2</bibl>, where Cic., speaking of himself, says: Cognosce nunc humanitatem meam, <hi rend="ital">learn from this</hi>, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">nomine audito extemplo agnovere virum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veterem amicum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">matrem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 405</bibl></cit>: Figulum in patriam suam venisse atque ibi agnosci, <hi rend="ital">and is there recognized</hi> (by those who had already known him), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:2:26" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 2, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">formas quasdam nostrae pecuniae agnoscunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agnoscent Britanni suam causam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nitorem et altitudinem horum temporum agnoscimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam (tunicam) cum agnovisset pater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:37:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 37, 33</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1603.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, as a result of this knowledge or recognition, <hi rend="ital">to declare</hi>, <hi rend="ital">announce</hi>, <hi rend="ital">allow</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">admit a thing to be one's own</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to acknowledge</hi>, <hi rend="ital">own</hi>: qui mihi tantum tribui dicis, quantum ego nec agnosco (<hi rend="ital">neither can admit as due to me</hi>) nec postulo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">natum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeacon agnoscit summus prolemque fatetur Juppiter esse suam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 27</bibl></cit> (cf. in Pandects, 25, Tit. 3: <cit><quote lang="la">de agnoscendis vel alendis liberis): an me non agnoscetis ducem?</quote> <trans><tr>will you not acknowledge me as your general?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agnoscere bonorum possessionem,</quote> <trans><tr>to declare the property as one's own</tr>, <tr>to lay claim to it</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:26:8:11" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 26, 8, 11</bibl></cit> (cf. agnitio, I.): <cit><quote lang="la">agnoscere aes alienum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:5:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 28, 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facti gloriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">susciperem hoc crimen, agnoscerem, confiterer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Perd. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortasse minus expediat agnoscere crimen quam abnuere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sortilegos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:58:132" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 58, 132</bibl></cit>: et ego ipse me non esse verborum admodum inopem agnosco, <hi rend="ital">and I myself confess</hi>, <hi rend="ital">allow</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 4, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">id ego agnovi meo jussu esse factum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 20, 3</bibl></cit>: carmina spreta exolescunt; <cit><quote lang="la">si irascare, agnita videntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 34</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1603.3" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To understand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">recognize</hi>, <hi rend="ital">know</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perceive</hi> by, from, or through something: <cit><quote lang="la">ut deum agnoscis ex operibus ejus, sic ex memoriā rerum et inventione, vim divinam mentis agnoscito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:28:70" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 28, 70</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:14:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 14, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex fructu arbor agnoscitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:12:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 12, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inde agnosci potest vis fortunae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:116:3" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 116, 3</bibl></cit>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: Augusti laudes agnoscere possis, <hi rend="ital">you can recognize the praises of Augustus</hi>, * <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 16, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accipio agnoscoque deos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 260</bibl></cit> (cf. accipio): <cit><quote lang="la">agniti dempsere sollicitudinem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Germanicus, quo magis agnosceretur, detraxerat tegimen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terram non agnoscebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:27:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 27, 39</bibl></cit>.—In gen., <hi rend="ital">to become acquainted with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to know; to perceive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">apprehend</hi>, <hi rend="ital">understand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">discern</hi>, <hi rend="ital">remark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">see</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin puppim flectis, Ulixe, Auribus ut nostros possis agnoscere cantus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:18:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 18, 49</bibl></cit> (as transl. of Hom. Od. 12, 185, <foreign lang="greek">*nh=a kata/sthson, i(/na nwi+te/rhn o)/p) a)kou/sh|s</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">haec dicta sunt subtilius ab Epicuro quam ut quivis ea possit agnoscere,</quote> <trans><tr>understand</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:18:49" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 18, 49</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:843" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 843</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:2:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 2, 5, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alienis pedibus ambulamus, alienis oculis agnoscimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 1, 8, § 19</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agnus: <entryFree id="n1604" type="main" key="agnus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agnus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<sense id="n1604.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> agnūm, Porc. Licin. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:9:13" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 9, 13</bibl>) [cf. <foreign lang="greek">a)mno/s</foreign>, which <pb n="74" /> <cb n="AGO" /> Benfey connects with <foreign lang="greek">o)/i+s</foreign> = Sanscr. avis; Lith. ávinas = sheep], <hi rend="ital">a lamb</hi>, usually for sacrifice: TERTIA. SPOLIA. IANO. QVIRINO. AGNOM. MAREM. CAEDITO, from an ancient law (of Numa?), in Fest. s. v. opima, p. 190: IVNONI. CRINIBVS. DEMISSIS. AGNAM. FEMINAM. CAEDITO., from a law of Numa in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:33" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 33</bibl>, and Fest. s. v. pellices, p. 121: <cit><quote lang="la">jam ego te hic agnum faciam et medium distruncabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 54</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:2:4 al" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 2, 4 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agnus absque maculā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:12:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 12, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agnos immaculatos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:14:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Lev. 14, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">villa abundat porco, haedo, agno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 16, 56</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:11:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 11, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:320" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 320</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:18:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 18, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ara avet immolato Spargier agno,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 11, 8</bibl></cit> al.—Prov.: Agnum lupo eripere velle, <hi rend="ital">to wish to rescue a lamb from a wolf</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to wish what is impossible</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 5, 31</bibl>.—Eccl. Lat., of Christ: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi agni immaculati Christi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 1</bibl></cit> Pet. 1, 19: <cit><quote lang="la">Ecce Agnus Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 1, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ceciderunt coram Agno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:5:8 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 5, 8 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
ago: <entryFree id="n1605" type="main" key="a^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgo</orth>, <itype>ēgi, actum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (axim = egerim, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 505, 22</bibl>; Paul. ex Fest. s. v. axitiosi, p. 3 Müll.; <sense id="n1605.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">axit = egerit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Diac. 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">AGIER = agi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 15</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">agentūm = agentium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulc. Gall.</author> Av. Cass. 4, 6</bibl></cit>) [cf. <foreign lang="greek">a)/gw</foreign>; Sanscr. aǵ, aghāmi = to go, to drive; agmas = way, train = <foreign lang="greek">o)/gmos</foreign>; agis = race, contest = <foreign lang="greek">a)gw/n</foreign>; perh. also Germ. jagen, to drive, to hunt], <hi rend="ital">to put in motion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to move</hi> (syn.: agitare, pellere, urgere). </sense><sense id="n1605.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1605.2" n="A" level="2"> Of cattle and other animals, <hi rend="ital">to lead</hi>, <hi rend="ital">drive.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1605.3" n="a" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: agas asellum, Seip. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:64:258" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 64, 258</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jumenta agebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capellas ago,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pars quia non veniant pecudes, sed agantur, ab actu etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:323" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 323</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caballum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 18, 36</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.4" n="b" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">acc. of place</hi>, <pos>prep.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">agere bovem Romam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:1:45" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 1, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equum in hostem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Germani in amnem aguntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 5, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acto ad vallum equo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecora per calles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per devia rura capellas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:676" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 676</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus pastum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:41, p. 88" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, 41, p. 88</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">capellas potum age,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 9, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus egit altos Visere montes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 2, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.5" n="B" level="2"> Of men, <hi rend="ital">to drive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lead</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conduct</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impel.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1605.6" n="a" level="4"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmen agens equitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:804" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 804</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.7" n="b" level="4"> With <pos>prep.</pos>, <case>abl.</case>, or <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vinctum ante se Thyum agebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agitur praeceps exercitus Lydorum in populos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:720" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 720</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(adulteram) maritus per omnem vicum verbere agit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:27" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">captivos prae se agentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:6" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acti ante suum quisque praedonem catenati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:69" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">captivos sub curribus agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:8:26" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 8, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agimur auguriis quaerere exilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 5</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and simple for comp.: multis milibus armatorum actis ex ea regione = coactis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 31</bibl></cit>.— In prose: agi, <hi rend="ital">to be led</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to march</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to go</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo multitudo omnis consternata agebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 29</bibl></cit>: si citius agi vellet agmen, <hi rend="ital">that the army would move</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">march on quicker</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">raptim agmine acto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 28</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:9" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 9</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">egit sol hiemem sub terras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poëmata dulcia sunto Et quocumque volent animum auditoris agunto,</quote> <trans><tr>lead the mind</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 100</bibl></cit>. —Hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: se agere, <hi rend="ital">to betake one's self</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to go</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to come</hi> (in Plaut. very freq.; <cit><quote lang="la">also in Ter., Verg., etc.): quo agis te?</quote> <trans><tr>where are you going?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:294" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 294</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unde agis te?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 4, 28</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:2:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 2, 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 120</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 4, 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 3, 71</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo hinc te agis?</quote> <trans><tr>where are you going</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ecce gubernator sese Palinurus agebat,</quote> <trans><tr>was moving along</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:337" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 337</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeneas se matutinus agebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 465</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">is enim se primus agebat,</quote> <trans><tr>for he strode on in front</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 696</bibl></cit>.—Also without <hi rend="ital">se</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Et tu, unde agis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quo agis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:2:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 2, 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Huc age,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:2" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 2</bibl></cit> (unless age is here to be taken with veni at the end of the line).—</sense><sense id="n1605.8" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To drive</hi> or <hi rend="ital">carry off</hi> (animals or men), <hi rend="ital">to steal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rob</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plunder</hi> (usually abigere): <cit><quote lang="la">Et redigunt actos in sua rura boves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:64" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 64</bibl></cit>.—So esp. freq. of men or animals taken as booty in war, while <hi rend="ital">ferre</hi> is used of portable things; hence, ferre et agere (as in Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)/gein kai\ fe/rein</foreign>, Hom. Il. 5, 484; and reversed, <foreign lang="greek">fe/rein kai\ a)/gein</foreign>, in Hdt. and Xen.; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">rapiunt feruntque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:374" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 374</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rapere et auferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 14</bibl></cit>), in gen., <hi rend="ital">to rob</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to plunder</hi>: res sociorum ferri<cb n="AGO" />  agique vidit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ferri agique res suas viderunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 38, 15</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 37</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so also: rapere agereque: ut ex alieno agro raperent agerentque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 1, 2</bibl></cit>; but portari atque agi means <hi rend="ital">to bear and carry</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bring together</hi>, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 29</bibl> (as <foreign lang="greek">fe/rein kai\ a)/gein</foreign> in Plat. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:279" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 279</bibl>, C): <cit><quote lang="la">ne pulcram praedam agat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbes, agros vastare, praedas agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 20, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:32:3" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecoris et mancipiorum praedas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 44:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 44, 5</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so eccl. Lat.: agere praedas de aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,026:9:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jud. 9, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:27:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Reg. 27, 8</bibl>; cf. Gron. Obs. 3, 22, 633.—</sense><sense id="n1605.9" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To chase</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pursue</hi>, <hi rend="ital">press</hi> animals or men, <hi rend="ital">to drive</hi> about or onwards in flight (for the usual agitare). </sense><sense id="n1605.10" n="a" level="4"> Of animals: <cit><quote lang="la">apros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:412" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 412</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cervum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:481" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 7, 481</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 71</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">citos canes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 5, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">feros tauros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.11" n="b" level="4"> Of men: <cit><quote lang="la">ceteros ruerem, agerem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 2, 21</bibl></cit> (= prosequerer, premerem, Don.): <cit><quote lang="la">ita perterritos egerunt, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Demoleos cursu palantis Troas agebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:265" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 265</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 574</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem in exsilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:9:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 2, 9, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:16:4:4" default="NO">16, 4, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:17:3:17" default="NO">17, 3, 17</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">22, 1, 16 al.: aliquem in fugam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:16:2:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 16, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.12" n="E" level="2"> Of inanimate or abstract objects, <hi rend="ital">to move</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">push</hi> forwards, <hi rend="ital">advance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">carry</hi> to or toward any point: <cit><quote lang="la">quid si pater cuniculos agat ad aerarium?</quote> <trans><tr>lead</tr>, <tr>make</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:23:90" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 23, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">egisse huc Alpheum vias,</quote> <trans><tr>made its way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:695" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 695</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vix leni et tranquillo mari moles agi possunt,</quote> <trans><tr>carry</tr>, <tr>build out</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:2:8" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cloacam maximam sub terram agendam,</quote> <trans><tr>to be carried under ground</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 56</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so often in the histt., esp. Cæs. and Livy, as t. t., of moving forwards the battering engines: celeriter vineis ad oppidum actis,</quote> <trans><tr>pushed forwards</tr>, <tr>up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 12</bibl></cit> Herz.; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 21</bibl>; 7, 17; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accelerant acta pariter testudine Volsci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:505 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 505 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fugere colles campique videntur, quos agimus praeter navem, i. e. praeter quos agimus navem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:391" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 391</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in litus passim naves egerunt,</quote> <trans><tr>drove the ships ashore</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ratem in amnem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:500" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 500</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">naves in advorsum amnem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 22</bibl></cit>.— <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: agere navem, <hi rend="ital">to steer</hi> or <hi rend="ital">direct a ship</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 114</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">agere currum,</quote> <trans><tr>to drive a chariot</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 62</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 388 al.</bibl>— </sense><sense id="n1605.13" n="F" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To stir up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to throw out</hi>, <hi rend="ital">excite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cause</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bring forth</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">scintillasque agere ac late differre favillam,</quote> <trans><tr>to throw out sparks and scatter ashes far around</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:675" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 675</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spumas ore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 203</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 66</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">piceum Flumen agit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:814" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 814</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui vocem cubantes sensim excitant, eandemque cum egerunt, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>when they have brought it forth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:59:251" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 59, 251</bibl></cit>. —Hence, animam agere, <hi rend="ital">to expel the breath of life</hi>, <hi rend="ital">give up the ghost</hi>, <hi rend="ital">expire</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">agens animam spumat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:493" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 493</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anhelans vaga vadit, animam agens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 63, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam et agere animam et efflare dicimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:9:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 9, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hortensius, cum has litteras scripsi, animam agebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 8, 13, 2</bibl></cit>; so Cael. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eodem tempore et gestum et animam ageres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:chapter=8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Est tanti habere animam ut agam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 101:12" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 101, 12</bibl></cit>; and with a play upon words: semper agis causas et res agis, Attale, semper. Est, non est, quod agas, Attale, semper agis. Si res et causae desunt, agis, Attale, mulas; <cit><quote lang="la">Attale, ne quod agas desit, agas animam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:80" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 80</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.14" n="G" level="1"> Of plants, <hi rend="ital">to put forth</hi> or <hi rend="ital">out</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to shoot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">extend</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(salices) gemmas agunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:30" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">florem agere coeperit ficus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 5:10:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 5, 10, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frondem agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 6, 8, § 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se ad auras palmes agit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:364" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 364</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(platanum) radices trium et triginta cubitorum egisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:37:15" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 37, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per glebas sensim radicibus actis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:254" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 254</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:2:583" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 583</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">robora suas radices in profundum agunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 31, 56, § 127</bibl></cit>.—Metaph.: <cit><quote lang="la">vera gloria radices agit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:12:43" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 12, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pluma in cutem radices egerat imas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:582" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 582</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n1605.15" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1605.16" n="A" level="2"> Spec., <hi rend="ital">to guide</hi>, <hi rend="ital">govern</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tros Tyriusque mihi nullo discrimine agetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:574" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 574</bibl></cit>; cf. Forbig. ad h. 1., who considers it the only instance of this use, and compares a similar use of <foreign lang="greek">a)/gw</foreign>; v. L. and S. s. v. II. 2.—</sense><sense id="n1605.17" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to move</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">excite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">urge</hi> to a thing, <hi rend="ital">to prompt</hi> or <hi rend="ital">induce</hi> to: <cit><quote lang="la">si quis ad illa deus te agat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 7, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">una plăga ceteros ad certamen egit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 41</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:7" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:15" default="NO" valid="yes">39, 15</bibl>: quae te, germane, <cb n="AGO" /> furentem Mens agit in facinus? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">totis mentibus acta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:191" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 10, 191</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in furorem agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:31" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si Agricola in ipsam gloriam praeceps agebatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">provinciam avaritia in bellum egerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 14, 32</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.18" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To drive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stir up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">excite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">agitate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rouse vehemently</hi> (cf. agito, II.): <cit><quote lang="la">me amor fugat, agit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:2:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 2, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agunt eum praecipitem poenae civium Romanorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perpetua naturalis bonitas, quae nullis casibus neque agitur neque minuitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 9, 1</bibl></cit> Brem.: <cit><quote lang="la">opportunitas, quae etiam mediocres viros spe praedae transvorsos agit,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>leads astray</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 6, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:14:20" default="NO" valid="yes">14, 20</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 8:3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 8, 3</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">To pursue with hostile intent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to persecute</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disturb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vex</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to attack</hi>, <hi rend="ital">assail</hi> (for the usu. agitare; mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">reginam Alecto stimulis agit undique Bacchi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:405" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 405</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non res et agentia (i. e. agitantia, vexantia) verba Lycamben,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 19, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerba fata Romanos agunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod 7, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diris agam vos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam deus ultor agebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:750" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 750</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">futurae mortis agor stimulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:517" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 4, 517</bibl></cit>; cf. Matth. ad Cic. Mur. § 21.—</sense><sense id="n1605.19" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To drive at</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">to pursue a course of action</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to make something an object of action;</hi> either in the most general sense, like the Engl. <hi rend="ital">do</hi> and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">pra/ttein</foreign>, for every kind of mental or physical employment; or, in a more restricted sense, <hi rend="ital">to exhibit in external action</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to act</hi> or <hi rend="ital">perform</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to deliver</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pronounce</hi>, etc., so that after the act is completed nothing remains permanent, e. g. <hi rend="ital">a speech</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">play</hi>, etc. (while <hi rend="ital">facere</hi>, to make, <foreign lang="greek">poiei=n</foreign>, denotes the production of an object which continues to exist after the act is completed; and <hi rend="ital">gerere</hi>, the performance of the duties of an office or calling).—On these significations, v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:6:6:62" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> 6, 6, 62</bibl>, and 6, 7, 64, and 6, 8, 72.—For the more restricted signif. v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:18:1 sq" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 18, 1 sq.</bibl>; cf. Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 12</bibl>; Hab. Syn. 426. </sense><sense id="n1605.20" n="1" level="3"> In the most gen. signif., <hi rend="ital">to do</hi>, <hi rend="ital">act</hi>, <hi rend="ital">labor</hi>, in opp. to rest or idleness. </sense><sense id="n1605.21" n="a" level="4"> With the gen. objects, <hi rend="ital">aliquid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nihil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plus</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam se plus agere quam nihil cum ageret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 17</bibl></cit> (cf. with this, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 1</bibl>: numquam se minus otiosum esse quam cum otiosus esset): mihi, qui nihil agit, esse omnino non videtur. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:16:46" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 16, 46</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">post satietatem nihil (est) agendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1605.22" n="b" level="4"> Without <hi rend="ital">object</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliud agendi tempus, aliud quiescendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:53:132" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 53, 132</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:16:49" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 16, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agendi tempora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">industria in agendo, celeritas in conficiendo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:10:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 10, 29</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.23" n="c" level="4"> In colloquial lang., <hi rend="ital">to do</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fare</hi>, <hi rend="ital">get on</hi>: quid agis? <hi rend="ital">what are you doing?</hi> M. Tulli, quid agis? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid agis?</quote> <trans><tr>What's your business?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 2, 9</bibl></cit>; also, <hi rend="ital">How goes it with you? How are you?</hi> <foreign lang="greek">ti pra/tteis</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:11 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 11 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vereor, quid agat,</quote> <trans><tr>how he is</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sciatis, quid agam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ephes. 6, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prospere agit anima tua,</quote> <trans><tr>fares well</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,025:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 3 Joan. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid agitur?</quote> <trans><tr>how goes it with you? how do you do? how are you?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 1, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 5, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 2, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid intus agitur?</quote> <trans><tr>is going on</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 5, 2, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:42 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 42 al.</bibl>— </sense><sense id="n1605.24" n="d" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">nihil</hi> or <hi rend="ital">non multum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to do</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to effect</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accomplish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">achieve nothing</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">not much</hi> (orig. belonging to colloquial lang., but in the class. per. even in oratorical and <usg type="style">poet.</usg> style): nihil agit; <cit><quote lang="la">collum obstringe homini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:5:3:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 5, 3, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil agis,</quote> <trans><tr>you effect nothing</tr>, <tr>it is of no use</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 8, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil agis, dolor! quamvis sis molestus, numquam te esse confitebor malum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:25:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 25, 61</bibl></cit> Kühn.; Matius ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:28:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 28, 10</bibl>: cupis, inquit, abire; sed nihil agis; <cit><quote lang="la">usque tenebo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">[nihil agis,] nihil assequeris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:6:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 6, 15</bibl></cit> B. and K.: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi blanditiis agitur nihil,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:685" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 685</bibl></cit>: egerit non multum, <hi rend="ital">has not done much</hi>, Curt. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 29</bibl>; cf. Ruhnk. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0425,001:page=120" default="NO"><author>Rutil.
