2, 11, 22; <cit><quote lang="la">3, 4, 1.—So also in prose (very rarely): Mittite agedum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">procedat agedum ad pugnam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.55" n="II" level="1"> It is often separated from such verb: <cit><quote lang="la">age me huc adspice,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 118</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 5, 2, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Age ... instiga,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 2, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 6, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quare agite ... conjungite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:372" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 372</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Huc age ... veni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:2" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ergo age cervici imponere nostrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:707" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 707</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">en age segnis Rumpe moras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 3, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">age te procellae Crede,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:27:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 27, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Age jam ... condisce,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 11, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 7, 4</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1605.56" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n1605.57" n="A" level="2"> <pos>Adj.</pos> </sense><sense id="n1605.58" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Efficient</hi>, <hi rend="ital">effective</hi>, <hi rend="ital">powerful</hi> (only in the rhet. lang. of Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">utendum est imaginibus agentibus, acribus, insignitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:87:358" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 87, 358</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acre orator, incensus et agens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:92:317" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 92, 317</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> not used.!*? </sense><sense id="n1605.59" n="2" level="3"> Agentia verba, in the grammarians, for <hi rend="ital">verba activa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.60" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgentes</orth>, ium. </sense><sense id="n1605.61" n="a" level="4"> Under the emperors, <hi rend="ital">a kind of secret police</hi> (also called <hi rend="ital">frumentarii</hi> and <hi rend="ital">curiosi</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 39" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 39 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:12" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 1, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:20" default="NO">1, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21" default="NO">21</bibl>; 22; 23, etc.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 15, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14, 11 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1605.62" n="b" level="4"> For agrimensores, <hi rend="ital">land-surveyors</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Lim. p. 179" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Lim. p. 179</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.63" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">actus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">that has been transacted</hi> in the Senate, in the forum, before the courts of justice, etc.; hence, </sense><sense id="n1605.64" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">actum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, a public <hi rend="ital">transaction</hi> in the Senate, before the people, or before a single magistrate: <cit><quote lang="la">actum ejus, qui in re publicā cum imperio versatus sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acta Caesaris servanda censeo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acta tui praeclari tribunatūs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 31</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.65" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">acta publĭca</orth>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">acta</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the register of public acts</hi>, <hi rend="ital">records</hi>, <hi rend="ital">journal.</hi> Julius Cæsar, in his consulship, ordered that the doings of the Senate (diurna acta) should be made public, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:20" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 20</bibl>; cf. Ernest. Exc. 1; <cit><quote lang="la">but Augustus again prohibited it,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:36" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 36</bibl></cit>. Still the acts of the Senate were written down, and, under the succeeding emperors. certain senators were appointed to this office (actis vel commentariis Senatūs conficiendis), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 5, 4</bibl>. They had also public registers of the transactions of the assemblies of the people, and of the different courts of justice; <cit><quote lang="la">also of births and deaths, marriages, divorces, etc., which were preserved as sources of future history.—Hence, diurna urbis acta,</quote> <trans><tr>the city journal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acta populi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:20" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acta publica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbana,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 9:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 15</bibl></cit>; which were all comprehended under the gen. name acta. </sense><sense id="n1605.66" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">With the time added</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acta eorum temporum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 13, 11, § 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illius temporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0803,001:Mil. 44:16" default="NO"><author>Ascon.</author> Mil. 44, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ejus anni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 56, 57, § 147</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.67" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">22, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">28, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 2:10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 2, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:3:16" default="NO">3, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:2:136" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 2, 136</bibl>: Quis dabit historico, quantum daret acta legenti, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to the</hi> actuarius, q. v., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:104" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 104</bibl>; cf. Bähr's Röm. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. 303.—</sense><sense id="n1605.68" n="C" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">acta triumphōrum</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the public record of triumphs</hi>, fuller than the <hi rend="ital">Fasti triumphales</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 2, 6, § 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.69" n="D" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">acta fŏri</orth> (v. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 445, 10</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">the records</hi>, </sense><sense id="n1605.70" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Of strictly historical transactions</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 22, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:6:33:section=1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 6, 33, § 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1605.71" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Of matters of private right</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as wills</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gifts</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bonds</hi> (acta ad jus privatorum pertinentia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:49:14:45:section=4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 49, 14, 45, § 4</bibl>), Fragm. Vat. §§ 249, 266, 268, 317.—</sense><sense id="n1605.72" n="E" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">acta mi-litarĭa</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the daily records of the movements of a legion</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> R. R. 2, 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agoce: <entryFree id="n1606" type="main" key="Agoce"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agoce</orth>, <itype>es</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1606.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Æthiopia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the borders of Egypt</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 29, 35, § 179</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agogae: <entryFree id="n1607" type="greek" key="a^go_gae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōgae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gwgai/</foreign> (or -<foreign lang="greek">oi/</foreign>) a conduit or aqueduct), in mines, <sense id="n1607.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">channels</hi> or <hi rend="ital">passages for drawing off water</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 4, 21, § 76</bibl>, v. Sillig ad h. l.</sense></entryFree>
agolum: <entryFree id="n1608" type="gloss" key="a^go^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgŏlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>from ago, as cingulum from cingo</etym>, <sense id="n1608.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a shepherd's staff</hi> or <hi rend="ital">crook</hi>: pastorale baculum, quo pecudes <hi rend="ital">aguntur</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=29" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 29</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
agon: <entryFree id="n1609" type="greek" key="a^go_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōn</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gw/n</foreign>, <sense id="n1609.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> <foreign lang="greek">w=nos</foreign> <hi rend="ital">a contest</hi> or <hi rend="ital">combat in the public games</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gymnicus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non esse restituendum Viennensibus agona,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 22</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">musicus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:22" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 22</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 23</bibl>.—Hence, prov.: nunc demum agon est = <foreign lang="greek">nu=n ga/r e)stin a)gw/n</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">now we must act</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now is the time for action</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:45" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 45</bibl>. <cb n="AGRA" /></sense></entryFree>
agonalia: <entryFree id="n1610" type="main" key="A^go_na_li^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgōnālĭa</orth>, <itype>ĭum or ōrum</itype> (like Saturnalia, Parentalia, etc.), <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1610.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a festival in honor of Janus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">celebrated in Rome on the</hi> 9<hi rend="ital">th of Jan.</hi> (V. Id. Jan.) <hi rend="ital">and</hi> 21<hi rend="ital">st of May</hi> (XII. Kal. Jun.).—Different derivations of the word were given by the ancients, concerning which see <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:319" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 319</bibl>-332. Ovid, in l. c., derives it from agonia, q. v. For other etym., <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the foll.</ref></xr> art., and under agonium.</sense></entryFree>
agonalis: <entryFree id="n1611" type="main" key="A^go_na_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgōnālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1611.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Agonalia</hi> (cf. preced. art.): dies Agonales, per quos rex in regiā arietem immolat; <cit><quote lang="la">dicti ab Agone (the leader, the chief), eo quod interrogatur a principe civitatis et princeps gregis immolatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=12" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 12</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">Janus Agonali luce piandus erit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:318" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 318</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agonensis: <entryFree id="n1612" type="gloss" key="A^go_nensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgōnensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <sense id="n1612.0" n="I" level="1"> Porta Agonensis, <hi rend="ital">one of the gates of Rome</hi>, also called Collina and Quirinalis, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. Agonium, p. 10 Müll.; cf. Smith's Dict. Antiq. —</sense><sense id="n1612.1" n="II" level="1"> Salii Agonenses, <hi rend="ital">the priests who officiated upon the</hi> Quirinalis (also called Agonus; <cit><quote lang="la">v. Agonium),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=14" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 14</bibl></cit> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
agonia: <entryFree id="n1613" type="gloss" key="a^go_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n1613.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A victim</hi>, v. agonium.—</sense><sense id="n1613.1" n="II" level="1"> = Agonalia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:721" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 721</bibl>; cf. agonium.</sense></entryFree>
agonista: <entryFree id="n1614" type="greek" key="a^go_nista^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōnistă</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gwnisth/s</foreign>, <sense id="n1614.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a combatant for a prize</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Serm. 343" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Serm. 343 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>‡ † <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōnistarcha</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gwnista/rxhs</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the superintendent of public games</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 38, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agonium: <entryFree id="n1615" type="gloss" key="a^go_ni^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōnĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>: dies appellabatur, quo rex (sacrificulus) hostiam immolabat. Hostiam enim antiqui agoniam vocabant. Agonium etiam putabant deum dici praesidentem rebus agendis; Agonalia ejus festivitatem, sive quia agones dicebant montes. Agonia sacrificia, quae fiebant in monte. Hinc Romae mons Quirinalis Agonus et Collina Agonensis, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=10" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 10</bibl> Müll.; and immediately foll., id. ib: Agonium id est, ludum, ob hoc dictum, quia locus, in quo ludi initio facti sunt, fuerit sine angulo; cujus festa Agonalia dicebantur; Agonium Martiale, Masurius ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 4</bibl>.</entryFree>
agonotheta: <entryFree id="n1616" type="main" key="a^go_no^the^ta^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōnŏthĕtă</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgōnŏthĕtēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gwnoqe/ths</foreign>, <sense id="n1616.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the superintendent of public games</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Hadr. 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Mart. 3 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
agonus: <entryFree id="n1617" type="gloss" key="A^go_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgōnus</orth>, v. agonium.</entryFree>
agoranomus: <entryFree id="n1618" type="greek" key="a^go^ra_no^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăgŏrānŏmus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gorano/mos</foreign> (clerk of the market), <sense id="n1618.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Grecian magistrate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who had the inspection of provisions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and their purchase and sale;</hi> the Aedilis plebis of the Romans, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 43</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agragantinus: <entryFree id="n1619" type="main" key="Agra^ganti_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrăgantīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, i.q. Acragantinus and Agrigentinus, v. Acragas.</entryFree>
agragas: <entryFree id="n1620" type="main" key="Agragas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agragas</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, i. q. Acragas, q. v., and Agrigentum.</entryFree>
agralis: <entryFree id="n1621" type="hapax" key="agra_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = agrarius: vocabula, Front. de Colon. <sense id="n1621.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
agrammatos: <entryFree id="n1622" type="greek" key="agramma^tos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrammătos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)gra/mmatos</foreign>, <sense id="n1622.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">illiterate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non debet esse architectus grammaticus, sed non agrammatos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 1, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agrarius: <entryFree id="n1623" type="main" key="a_^gra_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^grārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ager</etym>, <sense id="n1623.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to land;</hi> hence, </sense><sense id="n1623.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum operario agrario,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:37:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 37, 13</bibl></cit>.—But in class. Lat. a legal term: Agrariae leges, <hi rend="ital">agrarian laws</hi>, <hi rend="ital">relating to the division of public lands among the poorer citizens</hi>, first proposed about 268 A. U. C., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4" default="NO" valid="yes">4</bibl>. 36; 48; 6, 11; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:32 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 32 al.</bibl>; v. Smith's Dict. Antiq., and cf. Nieb. Rom. Hist. 2, 188; 197; 482; 490 al.; <cit><quote lang="la">with particular appellations from their authors, Flaminii, Sempronia, Thoria, Rulli, Flavii, Philippi, Plotia, Caesaris Julia, etc.—Hence, agrariam rem tentare,</quote> <trans><tr>to urge a division of public lands</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:22:78" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 22, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Triumvir agrarius,</quote> <trans><tr>superintendent of the division of public lands</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agrariae stationes, in milit. lang.,</quote> <trans><tr>outposts</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 1, 3</bibl>.—In the Pandects: <cit><quote lang="la">agraria via,</quote> <trans><tr>a way through the fields</tr>, <tr>private way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:8:2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 43, 8, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1623.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^grārĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">those who urged the agrarian laws</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and sought the possession of public land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the partisans of the agrarian laws</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Gracchus, qui agrarios concitare conatus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 4, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 7, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 1</bibl>. <cb n="AGRI" /></sense></entryFree>
agraticum: <entryFree id="n1624" type="hapax" key="agra_ti^cum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrātĭcum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>ager</etym>, <sense id="n1624.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a revenue from land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a land-tax</hi>, Cod. Th. 7, 20, 11.</sense></entryFree>
agrestis: <entryFree id="n1625" type="main" key="a_^grestis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^grestis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n1625.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fields</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">the country</hi>, <hi rend="ital">country</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rural</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rustic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wild</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)/grios</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">Musa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1397" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1397</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">te in Arpinati videbimus et hospitio agresti accipiemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,016:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Pel. 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">falx,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:28 al" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 28 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum lactucis agrestibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 12, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ligna non sunt pomifera, sed agrestia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:20:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Deut. 20, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">herbas agrestes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,014:4:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 4 Reg. 4, 39</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^gre-stis</orth>, <itype>is</itype> (<hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> agrestūm, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:635" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 635</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">a countryman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rustic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">farmer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peasant</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1382" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1382</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non est haec oratio habenda aut cum imperitā multitudine aut in aliquo conventu agrestium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">collectos armat agrestes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Fictilia antiquus primum sibi fecit agrestis Pocula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:1:39" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 1, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facinus admissum a quodam agresti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inopes agrestes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 50</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1625.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, and in mal. part. </sense><sense id="n1625.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Rustic</hi>, in opp. to the refined citizen (<hi rend="ital">urbanus</hi>, as <foreign lang="greek">a)/grios</foreign> is opp. to <foreign lang="greek">a)stei=os</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">boorish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">clownish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rude</hi>, <hi rend="ital">uncultivated</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coarse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wild</hi>, <hi rend="ital">savage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarous</hi>, of persons and things: <cit><quote lang="la">sunt quidam vultu motuque corporis vasti atque agrestes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:25:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 25, 115</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">O rem dignam, in quā non modo docti, verum etiam agrestes erubescant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:14:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 14, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aborigines, genus hominum agreste,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ego ille agrestis, saevos, tristis, parcus, truculentus, tenax Duxi uxorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis nostrūm tam animo agresti ac duro fuit, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:chapter=8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dominus agrestis et furiosus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exculto animo nihil agreste, nihil inhumanum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 45</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:767" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 767</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">rustica vox et agrestis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3</bibl>. —Hence, agrestiores Musae, <hi rend="ital">ruder</hi>, of the language of the bar, in opp. to more refined and polished eloquence, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:3:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 3, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1625.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Wild</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brutish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vultus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agrestem detraxit ab ore figuram Juppiter (of Io),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:31:13" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 31, 13</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, v. above.— * <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> agrestissimus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Ep. 7, 4</bibl>.— * <hi rend="ital">Adv. comp. neutr.</hi> agrestius, <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Hadr. 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agricola: <entryFree id="n1626" type="main" key="agri^co^la1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭcŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (Lucr. has <sense id="n1626.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> agricolūm in 4, 586, but reg. form in 2, 1161; 6, 1260) [ager-colo], <hi rend="ital">a cultivator of land</hi>, in the widest sense, <hi rend="ital">a husbandman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">agriculturist</hi> (including even <hi rend="ital">the vine-dresser</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gardener;</hi> also <hi rend="ital">one who takes pleasure in agriculture</hi>, etc.); or in a more limited sense, <hi rend="ital">a farmer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ploughman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">countryman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">boor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peasant</hi>. </sense><sense id="n1626.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">bonum agricolam laudabant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agricolae assidui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Deiotarus) optimus paterfamilias et diligentissimus agricola et pecuarius,</quote> <trans><tr>devoted to agriculture and cattlebreeding</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed venio ad agricolas,</quote> <trans><tr>the farmers</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agricolam laudat juris peritus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invisum agricolis sidus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sollers,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Cat. 3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Cat. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">peritissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 1:11:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 1, 11, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortunati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:468" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 468</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">indomiti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:521" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 7, 521</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parvo beati,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negotiosi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:R. R. 9:2:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> R. R. 9, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">severi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1356" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1356</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">miseri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:292" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 292</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 4, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Jacob. 5, 7</bibl>.—Of the <hi rend="ital">vine-dresser</hi>, <hi rend="ital">keeper of a vineyard</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">locavit eam (vineam) agricolis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:21:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 21, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 15, 1</bibl>.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n1626.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, of the gods, <hi rend="ital">patrons</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tutelary deities of agriculture</hi>, as <hi rend="ital">Ceres</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Bacchus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Faunus</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">agricolarum duces di,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:1:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Redditur agricolis gratia caelitibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:1:36" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 1, 36</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1627" type="main" key="Agri^co^la2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrĭcŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1627.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman proper name</hi>: Cn. Julius, <hi rend="ital">a celebrated Roman commander</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father-in-law of Tacitus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who wrote his life</hi>, v. Tac. Agr.</sense></entryFree>
agricolaris: <entryFree id="n1628" type="main" key="agri^co^la_ris"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭcŏlāris</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. agricola</etym>, <sense id="n1628.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to farmers</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">opus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> Insit. 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agricolatio: <entryFree id="n1629" type="main" key="agri^co^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭcŏlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>agricolor</etym>, = agri cultura, <sense id="n1629.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">agriculture</hi>, <hi rend="ital">husbandry</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:1:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:1:12 al" default="NO">1, 1, 12 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
agricolor: <entryFree id="n1630" type="hapax" key="agri^co^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭcŏlor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>1. agricola</etym>, <sense id="n1630.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to cultivate land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to pursue agriculture</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Alb. 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
agricultio: <entryFree id="n1631" type="main" key="agri^culti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭcultĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, better separately, <orth extent="full" lang="la">agri cultĭo</orth>, <sense id="n1631.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">husbandry</hi> (only twice in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">si agri cultionem sustuleris, Verr. 2, 3, 97: qui se agri cultione oblectabant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 16</bibl></cit>. <pb n="78" /> <cb n="AH" /></sense></entryFree>
agricultor: <entryFree id="n1632" type="main" key="agri^cultor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭcultor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, better separately, <orth extent="full" lang="la">agri cultor</orth>, <sense id="n1632.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an agriculturist</hi>, <hi rend="ital">farmer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">husbandman</hi> (in class. per. very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">servos agri cultores rem publicam abduxisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 35</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:22:3:25:section=1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 22, 3, 25, § 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agricultura: <entryFree id="n1633" type="main" key="agri^cultu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭcultūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, better separately, <orth extent="full" lang="la">agri cultūra</orth>, <sense id="n1633.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">agriculture.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1633.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">insitiones, quibus nihil invenit agri culturā sollertius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:42" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agri culturae studere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo agri culturae deditus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,016:26:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Par. 26, 10</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1633.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">Dei agri cultura estis,</quote> <trans><tr>God's husbandry</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Cor. 3, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agrigentum: <entryFree id="n1634" type="main" key="Agri^gentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrĭgentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1634.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the largest and richest cities on the south coast of Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near Cape Pachynum</hi>, acc. to the Greek (<foreign lang="greek">*)akra/gas</foreign>) sometimes called Acragas or Agragas, now <hi rend="ital">Girgenti.</hi>—Here was the temple of Juno Lucina, so renowned in antiquity, whose ruins are still to be seen: <cit><quote lang="la">oppidum Acragas, quod Agrigentum nostri dixere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alia judicia Lilybaei, alia Agrigenti restituta sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 26</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrĭgentīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">from Agrigentum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 7, 41, § 85</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrĭgentīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Agrigentum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 50</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agrimensor: <entryFree id="n1635" type="main" key="agri_mensor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrī-mensor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ager</etym>, <sense id="n1635.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a landsurveyor</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 19, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 3, 52</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agrimonia: <entryFree id="n1636" type="main" key="agri^mo_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭmōnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, a false read. for argemonia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 9, 56, § 102</bibl> Jan.)</entryFree>
agriophyllon: <entryFree id="n1637" type="hapax" key="agri^o^phyllon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭŏphyllon</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)grio/fullon</foreign>, <sense id="n1637.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an herb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">otherwise called</hi> peucedanum (or -us) = <foreign lang="greek">peuke/danon</foreign> (or -<foreign lang="greek">os</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">hog's-fennel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sulphurwort</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 95</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agripeta: <entryFree id="n1638" type="main" key="agri^pe^ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭpĕta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ager-peto</etym>, <sense id="n1638.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who strives for the possession of land</hi>, either honorably or dishonorably (only in Cic.), N. D. 1, 26; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Att. 15, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">16, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agrippa: <entryFree id="n1639" type="main" key="Agrippa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrippa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1639.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman family name.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1639.1" n="I" level="1"> Menenius Agrippa, who related to the people upon Mons Sacer the fable of the Belly and the Limbs, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 32</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1639.2" n="II" level="1"> Vipsanius Agrippa, <hi rend="ital">son-in-law of Augustus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">husband of Julia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and father of Agrippina</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 40</bibl>; v. Frandsen, Life of M. Vipsanius Agrippa, Alton. 1836.—</sense><sense id="n1639.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of a king in Judœa</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agrippina: <entryFree id="n1640" type="main" key="Agrippi_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrippīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1640.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of several Roman women.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1640.1" n="I" level="1"> The wife of the emperor Tiberius, granddaughter of Atticus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1640.2" n="II" level="1"> A daughter of Vipsanius Agrippa and Julia, granddaughter of Augustus, wife of Germanicus, and mother of the emperor Caligula, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 54</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1640.3" n="III" level="1"> Daughter of the preced. and Germanicus, wife of Cn. Domitius Aënobarbus, and mother of the emperor Nero, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 75</bibl>. From her a colony planted on the Rhine received the name Colonia Agrippina, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 27</bibl>, or Agrippinensis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 57</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 55</bibl> (now <hi rend="ital">Cologne</hi>); and <hi rend="ital">its inhabitants</hi> were called Agrippinenses, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agrius: <entryFree id="n1641" type="greek" key="agri^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/grios</foreign>, <sense id="n1641.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wild</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(nitrum) sordidum terrā, a quā appellant agrium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 10, 46, § 106</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1642" type="main" key="Agri^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Agrĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-os</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1642.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">son of Parthaon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and father of Thersites</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:9:153" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 9, 153</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agrostis: <entryFree id="n1643" type="greek" key="agro_stis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrōstis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/grwstis</foreign>, <sense id="n1643.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">couchgrass</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quitch-grass</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 77</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agrosus: <entryFree id="n1644" type="hapax" key="agro_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ager</etym>, <sense id="n1644.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">rich in land</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=13" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 13</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
agrypnia: <entryFree id="n1645" type="greek" key="agrypni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">agrypnĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)grupni/a</foreign>, <sense id="n1645.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sleeplessness;</hi> in pure Lat., insomnium or vigilia, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 2, p. 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agyieus: <entryFree id="n1646" type="greek" key="A^gyi_eus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgyīeus</orth>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aguieu/s</foreign> (trisyl.), ĕï or eos, <sense id="n1646.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an epithet of Apollo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as guardian deity of the streets</hi> (<foreign lang="greek">a)guiai/</foreign>), since his statues stood in them: <cit><quote lang="la">levis Agyieu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:6:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 6, 27</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
agylla: <entryFree id="n1647" type="main" key="A^gylla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgylla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1647.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Etruria</hi>, called later Caere, now <hi rend="ital">Cervetri</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:479" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 479</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 8, § 51</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgyllīni</orth>, <hi rend="ital">inhabitants of Agylla</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:281" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 281</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
agyrium: <entryFree id="n1648" type="main" key="A^gy_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgȳrĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1648.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very old town in Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from Enna</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the birthplace of Diodorus Siculus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">S. Filippo d'Argiro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 28</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgyrĭnen-ses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 28</bibl>; or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăgyrī-ni</orth>, <itype>orum</itype>, <hi rend="ital">inhabitants of Agyrium</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 91</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ah: <entryFree id="n1649" type="main" key="a_h"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āh</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ā</orth> (v. Neue, Formenl. II. 812), <pos>interj.</pos> <cb n="AIO" /> [acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 570</bibl> P. contract. from aha], <sense id="n1649.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ah! alas! ha! ah me!</hi> an exclamation. </sense><sense id="n1649.1" n="I" level="1"> Of pain or grief, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ai)/, ai)/</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">ah, nescis quam doleam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 1, 15</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1649.2" n="II" level="1"> Of entreaty to avert an evil: <cit><quote lang="la">ah! noli,</quote> <trans><tr>do not</tr>, <tr>I pray!</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 22</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1649.3" n="III" level="1"> Of indignation or reproach: <cit><quote lang="la">ah stulte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 7, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ah, rogitas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 5, 1, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3, 1, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1649.4" n="IV" level="1"> Of admonition: <cit><quote lang="la">ah, ne me obsecra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ah desine,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 6, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1649.5" n="V" level="1"> Of consolation: <cit><quote lang="la">quid? ah volet, certo scio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 50</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1649.6" n="VI" level="1"> Of raillery or joy, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 39</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aha: <entryFree id="n1650" type="main" key="a^ha^"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhă</orth>, <pos>interj.</pos> <etym>acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 570</bibl> P., primitive of the preced., but more rare</etym>, <sense id="n1650.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">aha! ah! haha!</hi> an exclamation. </sense><sense id="n1650.1" n="I" level="1"> Of reproof or denial: <cit><quote lang="la">aha, tace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 4, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 2, 4, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aha, minime,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 54</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1650.2" n="II" level="1"> Of laughter, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:7:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 7, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ahala: <entryFree id="n1651" type="main" key="A^ha_la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăhāla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1651.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman family name</hi>, e. g. C. Servilius Ahala, who slew the turbulent Maelius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:16:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 16, 56</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aharna: <entryFree id="n1652" type="main" key="Aharna"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aharna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1652.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Etruria</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ahenator: <entryFree id="n1653" type="main" key="a^he_na_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhēnātor</orth>, v. aëneator.</entryFree>
aheneus: <entryFree id="n1654" type="main" key="a^he_ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăhēnĕus</orth>, <itype>ahenipes</itype>, etc., v. aën-.</entryFree>
ai: <entryFree id="n1655" type="main" key="ai1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ai</orth>, in old Lat., corresponding to ae: AIDILIS, CAISAR, AITERNOS, for Aedilis, Caesar, aeternus; also, still later, sometimes in the poets in the termination of the genitive of the first decl.; but, as in Enn. and Lucr., <sense id="n1655.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">per diaeresin</hi> always dissyl. with long penult: <cit><quote lang="la">furit intus aquāï,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:464" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 464</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurāï simplicis ignem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 747</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrāï frugiferāï,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:11:91:5" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 11, 91, 5</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:7:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 7, 18</bibl>; Spauld. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 728</bibl>; Prob. 1438; Vel. Long. 2222; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:Vict. 2460" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> Vict. 2460</bibl> P.—In prim. syllables, as in <case>voc.</case> Gaĭ, <hi rend="ital">ăi</hi> could not be changed to <hi rend="ital">ae</hi> if <hi rend="ital">i</hi> was an ending; but <hi rend="ital">i</hi> was changed to <hi rend="ital">i</hi> cons., when the word received accession, e. g. <hi rend="ital">Gaius.</hi>—When a conson. followed <hi rend="ital">ai</hi>, as in CNAIVOS for <foreign lang="greek">*g*n*a*iv*o*s</foreign> (v. the Epitaphs of the Scipios, in the Append.), <hi rend="ital">ae</hi> was written at a later per., as Gnaeus; hence from <foreign lang="greek">*gra/i+os</foreign> both Graecus and Graius; from <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/akos</foreign>, Aeacus, and Aiax, for <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/as</foreign>, were formed; just as Achaeus or Achivus with Achaĭus or Achaĭcus was used.</sense><sense id="n1655.1" n="2" level="3"> * <orth extent="full" lang="la">ai</orth> = <foreign lang="greek">ai)/</foreign>, <pos>interj.</pos>, denoting grief, <hi rend="ital">ah! alas!</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 215</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n1656" type="main" key="ai2" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ai</orth>, <sense id="n1656.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">imper.</hi>, from aio.</sense></entryFree>
aiens: <entryFree id="n1657" type="main" key="aiens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aiens</orth>, v. aio <sense id="n1657.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aientia: <entryFree id="n1658" type="hapax" key="aienti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aientĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aio</etym>, <sense id="n1658.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an affirmation</hi> (opp. negatio), <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 4, p. 75</bibl> Vulc.</sense></entryFree>
aio: <entryFree id="n1659" type="main" key="a_io"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āio</orth>, <sense id="n1659.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">verb. defect.</hi> The forms in use are: <hi rend="ital">pres. indic.</hi> āio, ăis, ait—aiunt; <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> aias, aiat—aiant; <hi rend="ital">imperf. indic.</hi> throughout, aiebam, aiebas, etc.; <hi rend="ital">imper.</hi> ai, rare; <hi rend="ital">part. pres.</hi> aiens, rare; once in <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6, p. 178</bibl> Elm.; and once as <pos>P. a.</pos> in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:11:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 11, 49</bibl>, v. below. Cic. wrote the <hi rend="ital">pres.</hi> aiio, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 11</bibl>.—From ais with the <hi rend="ital">interrog. part.</hi> ne, ain is used in colloquial language. For <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi> also aibas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aibat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 2, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aibant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 175</bibl></cit>; 4, 2, 102; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 3</bibl>; ai is dissyl., but in the <hi rend="ital">imper.</hi> also monosyl., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:5:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 5, 49</bibl>; cf. Bentl. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 6, 5</bibl>. Acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 818</bibl> P., the <hi rend="ital">pres.</hi> ait seems to take the place of a perf., but acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0996,001:1482" default="NO"><author>Val. Prob.</author> 1482</bibl> P., there was a real <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> ai, aisti, ait; <cit><quote lang="la">as aisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Ep. 54" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Ep. 54</bibl></cit> and 174: <cit><quote lang="la">aierunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Fuga in Persec. 6</bibl></cit>; the <hi rend="ital">pres. inf.</hi> aiere is found in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Trin. 9:10" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Trin. 9, 10</bibl> [cf. <foreign lang="greek">h)mi/</foreign> = I say; Sanscr. <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> 3d <number>sing.</number> āha = he spake; ad<hi rend="ital">ag</hi>ium, ad<hi rend="ital">ag</hi>io; negare for ne<hi rend="ital">ig</hi>are; Umbr. <hi rend="ital">ai</hi>tu = dicito; Engl. aye = yea, yes, and Germ. ja], <hi rend="ital">to say yes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to assent</hi> (opp. <hi rend="ital">nego</hi>, to say no; with the ending <hi rend="ital">-tumo</hi>, aiutumo; contract. autumo; opp. negumo; v. autumo). </sense><sense id="n1659.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: vel ai vel nega, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 473</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">veltu mihi aias vel neges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 4, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negat quis? nego. Ait? aio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Diogenes ait, Antipater negat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi ego id curem, quid ille aiat aut neget,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 22</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:12:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Post. 12, 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1659.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To say</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affirm</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">assert something</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">dicere</hi> signifies to speak in order to inform, and <hi rend="ital">affirmare</hi>, to speak in affirmation, Doed. Syn. 4, 6 sq.—Therefore different from <hi rend="ital">inquam</hi>, I say, I reply, since <cb n="AIO" /> aio is commonly used in indirect, and inquam in direct discourse; cf. Doed. as cited above; Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 48:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 48, 3</bibl>; and Ramsh. Gr. 800). </sense><sense id="n1659.4" n="a" level="4"> In indirect discourse: insanam autem illam (sc. esse) aiunt, quia, etc., Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,073:2:23:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Her. 2, 23, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 1, 1, 3</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Hodie uxorem ducis? <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> Aiunt, <hi rend="ital">they say so</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ait hac laetitiā Deiotarum elatum vino se obruisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">debere eum aiebat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tarquinium a Cicerone immissum aiebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 48:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 48, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vos sapere et solos aio bene vivere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 15, 45</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 2, 121</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 88</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 7, 22</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n1659.5" n="b" level="4"> In direct discourse: Ennio delector, ait quispiam, quod non discedit a communi more verborum; <cit><quote lang="la">Pacuvio, inquit alius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:11:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 11, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vos o, quibus integer aevi Sanguis, ait, solidaeque, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:639" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 639</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 630</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 121</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">12, 156: O fortunati mercatores! gravis annis Miles ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 15, 40</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 16, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:7:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 7, 72</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 3, 22</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.6" n="c" level="4"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Causa optumast, Nisi quid pater ait aliud,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Admirans ait haec,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:5:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 5, 3, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:84" default="NO" valid="yes">63, 84</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Haec ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:297" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 297</bibl></cit>; v. B.—</sense><sense id="n1659.7" n="B" level="2"> Simply <hi rend="ital">to speak</hi>, and esp. in the form of transition, sic ait, <hi rend="ital">thus he speaks</hi> or <hi rend="ital">says</hi> (cf. the Hom. <foreign lang="greek">w(\s fa/to</foreign>): <cit><quote lang="la">Sic ait, et dicto citius tumida aequora placat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:142" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 142</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 365</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 749</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Also of what follows: Sic ait in molli fixa toro cubitum: “Tandem,” etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:3:34" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 3, 34</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.8" n="C" level="2"> Ut ait quispiam (regularly in this order in Cic.), in quoting an unusual expression, <hi rend="ital">as one says</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Statius noster in Synephebis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Homerus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Theophrastus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:19:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 19, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Thucydides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait Cicero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:51" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1, 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:73" default="NO">8, 6, 73</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:40" default="NO">9, 4, 40</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">9, 56, 60: ut Cicero ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:7:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 7, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:3:11" default="NO">12, 3, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut Demosthenes ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut rumor ait,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:4:47" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 4, 47</bibl></cit>: uti mos vester ait, Hor S. 2, 7, 79.—So without <hi rend="ital">def. subject</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait in Synephebis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:14:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 14, 31</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1659.9" n="D" level="2"> Aiunt, ut aiunt, quemadmodum or quod aiunt, in quoting a proverbial or technical phrase, <hi rend="ital">as they say</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as is said</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as the saying is</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">to\ lego/menon, w(s fasi/</foreign>; Fr. on dit; <cit><quote lang="la">Germ. man sagt), either placed after it or interposed: eum rem fidemque perdere aiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 4, 2, 18</bibl></cit>: ut quimus, aiunt; <cit><quote lang="la">quando, ut volumus, non licet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 5, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">docebo sus, ut aiunt, oratorem eum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Iste claudus, quemadmodum aiunt, pilam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 28</bibl></cit> B. and K. —Also in telling an anecdote: <cit><quote lang="la">conspexit, ut aiunt, Adrasum quendam vacuā tonsoris in umbrā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 49</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 17, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.10" n="E" level="2"> In judic. lang.: ait lex, ait praetor, etc., <hi rend="ital">the law</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the prœtor says</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">prescribes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">commands</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut ait lex Julia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:3:64" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 24, 3, 64</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Praetor ait, in eadem causā eum exhibere, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:9:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 9, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aiunt aediles, qui mancipia vendunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:1:1" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 21, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ait oratio, fas esse eum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:1:32 al" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 24, 1, 32 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1659.11" n="F" level="1"> Ain? = aisne? also often strengthened: ain tu? ain tute? ain tandem? ain vero? in conversational lang., a form of interrogation which includes the idea of surprise or wonder, sometimes also of reproof or sorrow, <hi rend="ital">do you really mean so? indeed? really? is it possible?</hi> often only an emphatic <hi rend="ital">what?</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 4, 73</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Merc.</hi> Servus esne an liber? <hi rend="ital">Sos.</hi> Utcumque animo conlibitumst meo. <hi rend="ital">Merc.</hi> Ain vero? <hi rend="ital">Sos.</hi> Aio enim vero, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 4, 188</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 1, 128</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Phil.</hi> Pater, inquam, aderit jam hic meus. <hi rend="ital">Call.</hi> Ain tu, pater? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:3:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 2, 3, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 4, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 19</bibl> al: <cit><quote lang="la">Ain tu? Scipio hic Metellus proavum suum nescit censorem non fuisse?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 5 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ain tute,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ain tandem ita esse, ut dicis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 4, 19</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:5:2:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 5, 2, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 145</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 3, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ain tandem? insanire tibi videris, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 21</bibl></cit> Manut.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 2</bibl>.—Also with a <hi rend="ital">plur. verb</hi> (cf. age with <hi rend="ital">plur. verb</hi>, s. v. ago, IV. a.): <cit><quote lang="la">ain tandem? inquit, num castra vallata non habetis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.12" n="G" level="1"> Quid ais? (as in conversation).— </sense><sense id="n1659.13" n="a" level="4"> With the idea of surprise, astonishment, <foreign lang="greek">*ti/ le/geis</foreign> (cf. Quid dixisti? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 4, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:6:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 6, 16</bibl>, <foreign lang="greek">*ti/ ei)=pas</foreign>); <hi rend="ital">what do you say? what? Merc.</hi> Quis herus est igitur tibi? <hi rend="ital">Sos.</hi> Amphitruo, quicum nuptast Alcumena. <hi rend="ital">Merc.</hi> Quid ais? Quid nomen tibist? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:208" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 208</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.14" n="b" level="4"> When one asks <pb n="79" /> <cb n="ALA" /> another for his meaning, opinion, or judgment, <hi rend="ital">what do you mean? what do you say</hi> or <hi rend="ital">think? Th.</hi> Ita me di ament, honestust. <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> Quid tu ais, Gnatho? Num quid habes, quod contemnas? Quid tu autem, Thraso? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 2, 21</bibl>: Hunc ais? <hi rend="ital">Do you mean this man?</hi> (= dicis, q. v., II.) <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:4:27" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 4, 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1659.15" n="c" level="4"> When one wishes to try or prove another, <hi rend="ital">what is your opinion? what do you say?</hi> Sed quid ais? quid Amphitruoni [dono] a Telebois datumst? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:262" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 262</bibl>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">āiens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">affirming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affirmative</hi> (usu. affirmativus): <cit><quote lang="la">negantia contraria aientibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:11:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 11, 49</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ain: <entryFree id="n1660" type="main" key="ain"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ain</orth> = aisne, v. aio, II. F.</entryFree>
aithales: <entryFree id="n1661" type="greek" key="a^i_tha^les"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăīthăles</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)eiqale/s</foreign> (evergreen), <sense id="n1661.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also called</hi> Aizoon, <hi rend="ital">houseleek</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 123</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aiusloquens: <entryFree id="n1662" type="main" key="A_ius Lo^quens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Āius Lŏquens</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Āius Lŏcūtius</orth>, <sense id="n1662.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a deity among the Romans</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who made the announcement to them</hi>, <hi rend="ital">The Gauls are coming!</hi> Varr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:17:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 17, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aius iste Loquens, quando, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:32:69" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 32, 69</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">templum in Novā Viā Aio Locutio fieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 50</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 32</bibl>; cf. Becker, Antiq. vol. 4, p. 35.</sense></entryFree>
aizoon: <entryFree id="n1663" type="greek" key="a^i_zo_o^n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăīzōŏn</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ei/zwon</foreign> (ever-living), <sense id="n1663.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an evergreen plant.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1663.1" n="I" level="1"> Majus, <hi rend="ital">live-forever</hi>, <hi rend="ital">houseleek</hi>: Sempervivum tectorum, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 102, § 160</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1663.2" n="II" level="1"> Minus or minusculum, <hi rend="ital">stone-crop</hi>: Sedum album, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 102, § 160</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ajax: <entryFree id="n1664" type="main" key="A_jax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ājax</orth>, <itype>ācis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)/as</foreign>, <sense id="n1664.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of two Greeks renowned for their bravery.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1664.1" n="I" level="1"> Ajax Telamonius, <hi rend="ital">son of Telamon</hi>, who contended with Ulysses for the possession of the arms of Achilles, and, when the former obtained them, became insane and killed himself. From his blood the hyacinth sprang up, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:395" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 395</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1664.2" n="II" level="1"> Ajax Oileus, <hi rend="ital">son of Oileus</hi>, king of the Locri, who violated Cassandra, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 66</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1664.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The title of an unfinished tragedy of the emperor Augustus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:85" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 85</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
